title: GEN_MUS 101-6-1 First-Year Seminar
description_overview: This seminar is designed for the general campus student. Students with a music major, or a dual degree with music, are not permitted to register for this seminar. The course is designed to provide opportunities for music aficionados to experience music and music theater events from the inside-out. The only prerequisite for the course is a love of the performing arts - you don't have to read, perform, or understand music notation to succeed. However, you have to be prepared to spend a lot of time attending rehearsals and concerts (minimally six to eight hours a week), outside of the two required class sessions. During and outside of classroom sessions, the instructor and invited guests will attempt to nurture a heightened awareness of the challenges that conductors, opera and music theater directors and musicians/actors face when preparing for a performance. Through a series of observations, presentations, interviews, and interactive discussions/seminars, you will be better prepared to listen, observe, and critically analyze performing arts events on and off campus - during this academic quarter, and hopefully for the rest of your life. After Week One's introduction to the course and the music library, the Week Two class sessions will concentrate on conducting lessons and video observations of concerts and rehearsals. In these initial sessions, you will learn many of the techniques needed to lead the world's greatest instrumental and choral ensembles (of course, with many additional years of practice). Course participants, using their required conductor's baton and music CDs will learn a variety of conducting techniques - mastering beat patterns, the expressive use of the left hand, and using the conducting gesture to communicate interpretation, phrasing, dynamic shading. You may never conduct a major ensemble, but after meeting the requirements of the class you should have the knowledge and understanding to critically analyze conductors during your future career as a member of audiences for classical and popular music concerts.

title: GEN_MUS 230-0-1 History of Opera
description_overview: This introductory survey of opera covers a span of over 400 years in its exploration of the genre's history as a form of staged musical drama. Beginning with the fundamental building blocks of the genre?such as the makeup of the operatic orchestra and the cast of singers?the class will then cover opera's early 17th-century origins before then progressing through the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries, tracking opera's stylistic and thematic developments within each of these periods while also relating them to the larger sociopolitical changes which they may be seen to reflect. Students will be expected to participate in class discussions, regularly submit discussion posts in response to readings, and to view and listen to a selection of operas determined by the instructor.

title: GEN_MUS 170-0-1 Introduction to Music
description_overview: This course introduces students to new ways of thinking about music, by examining the connections between musical practice and social, political, and cultural values: What is the role of music in today's world and how did it shape the generations of the 20th century? Topics will be inclusive of popular and World music, as well as Western art music. Through readings, active listening, written assignments, and concert attendance, students will develop a better cultural awareness through musical knowledge. Assessments also include quizzes and exams for which students will be expected to prepare. This class does not require any prior musical training.

title: GEN_MUS 170-0-2 Introduction to Music
description_overview: This course functions as an introduction to music through the lenses of sound acoustics sound/music perception and cognition; and fundamental musical concepts. These concepts, or musical "elements," include patterns such as scales in addition to parameters of melody, dynamics, rhythm, harmony, texture, and timbre. Readings and discussions will pertain to a variety of topics, perspectives, and methods including: music and social function, music and language, music and philosophy, and notation. Students will be evaluated on the basis of reading responses, participation in class discussions, attendance, quizzes, and a final project.

title: GEN_MUS 170-0-3 Introduction to Music
description_overview: This course will be a concentrated survey of Western music from the Baroque period to the 20th century. With an emphasis on principal composers, musicians, and genres, we will examine and learn to appreciate aspects of musical style and aesthetics. Students will be expected to learn to recognize stylistic trends in music history, identify the works of major composers and/or schools of composition or performance, analyze music using appropriate vocabulary, and place musical works within their historical and social contexts. Student evaluation will be based on quizzes, a midterm and final exam, a presentation, participation, and exercises to be completed during each class meeting.

title: GEN_MUS 176-0-1 Selected Topics in Applied Music for Non-Majors
description_overview:
This course will serve as an introduction and workshop for practices of improvised music. While all forms of musicmaking involve some degree of spontaneity and active decision-making, free improvisation - in other words, playing without reference to any preconceived plan or genre (e.g. jazz, rock, or Indian classical music) - requires a unique set of skills. In this class, we will learn how to play "free" together by analyzing the foundations of our own musical languages, using practical musicianship exercises, as well as reading about the practice of improvised music as a late 20th-century genre and way of thinking.
Any musician of any skill level, style, or instrument (including voice, electronics, objects, or custom-made instruments) is welcome. The main qualification is having an open mind and arriving ready to play. Class will consist of discussions of assigned materials, workshops developing improvisational skill, and performances in and out of class.

title: GEN_MUS 175-0-1 Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors
description_overview: What does music have to do with painting? What does musical time have to do with biological rhythms and our perception of visual media? How does the combination of image and sound affect our experience with music videos, film, or live performances? In this course, we will investigate the historical and conceptual correspondences between music and the visual arts, with a particular emphasis on Western practice. We will cover a broad range of topics that includes but is not limited to impressionism, abstract expressionism, chance procedures, psychoacoustics and visual perception, sound installation, abstract and commercial animation, film and television, music videos, etc. Through this survey, we will seek to understand how the development and introduction of artistic movements and techniques were informed by creators from the two disciplines, with the hope that this knowledge will open new modes of thinking for our own practice as creative individuals. Student evaluation will be based on active participation in class discussions, reading and listening assignments, written work, and final presentations.

title: GEN_MUS 175-0-2 Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors
description_overview: Haunting, traditional, ancient, local, and ethereal are just some of the words used to describe "Celtic music" when it is heard today, whether at a Riverdance performance, on the Lord of the Rings soundtrack, or in the Black & White video game series. The term remains extremely ambiguous, however, and this class will interrogate the idea of "Celtic music" and its place in 20th- and 21st-century popular culture. Our examination begins by understanding the historical evolution of the umbrella term "Celtic" and the host of national, cultural, ethnic, and linguistic associations that it has come to represent. We will undertake case studies of music from the different regions affiliated with Celtic identity - Ireland, Scotland, Wales, and Brittany, among others - to garner a foundation for approaching the eclectic range of styles and genres typically categorized as "Celtic." Assigned readings and listening examples will be explored in class discussion with student assessment based on participation, listening quizzes, short essays, and weekly journals.

title: 216-0-1 Music in the Present
description_overview:
This course explores contemporary music through its circulation, reception, and mediation. Examples are drawn from Western art, popular, and global musical genres though we will explore how all these musics share?at least in part?similar modes of distribution. In the first unit we will learn how recording technologies and globalizing initiatives have fundamentally reshaped musical practices in the past hundred years. We will learn how musical commodities have been gradually dematerialized?transformed from radio broadcasts, vinyl records, and compact discs which have in turn been supplanted by streaming data.
The second unit of the course focuses on how the use of new technologies have led to changes in listening practices and aesthetics. We will think about personal listening habits?the "soundtracking" of everyday life?and the uses of music for emotional management. We will also consider changes in musical taste from hierarchical aesthetics based on high/low distinctions to forms of "omnivorous" listening. We'll consider how these changes in aesthetics have impacted concert music institutions and produced more permeable boundary between commercial genres and traditionally classical ensembles.
The final unit of the course will explore how musicians have responded to the changes in technology and listening practices. Drawing on a range of institutions, ensembles, and record labels, we will examine how musicians create sustainable communities by both harnessing and resisting new technologies and aesthetic values.

title: 435-0-1 Selected Topics
description_overview:
This course emphasizes the oral and written communication skills relative to music performance. The ability to speak and write about music in a scholarly manner is an essential attribute for aspiring performers and an expectation for anyone seeking a position in an academic environment.

In addition, this course affords students the opportunity to recognize and address the strengths and weaknesses in their own communication skills by way of course projects and activities. To reinforce the concepts covered in the course, students will be asked to organize and deliver oral presentations and produce written pieces designed to demonstrate and enhance their writing proficiency.

title: MUS_COMP 311-0-1 Class Composition
description_overview: This course is designed to provide an introduction for students of any background to the tools, techniques, and concerns involved in the creation of original music. In addition to creative composition assignments, students will develop an understanding of the basic elements of sound and music through listening assignments covering a range of repertoire within the Western classical and popular music traditions. Students will also be responsible for realizing their compositions either by performing the work themselves, recruiting friends/collaborators, or through video/audio recordings. This class does not require any previous knowledge or experience with music theory and/or music creation, but does require everyone's willingness to create and share their original works in class.

title: MUS_COMP 437-0-1 Topics in Contemporary Repertoire
description_overview:
A graduate workshop that gives a platform for experimentation and discussion of current compositional praxis.

The class is strongly project centered: everyone brings or develops artistic research projects with a strong praxis related aspect that will be worked on as a group. These projects can include areas such as microtonality, rhythmic patterns, space, noise and extended techniques, music and video, or really anything else of interest; they can be part of or relate to current compositions the students work on, or be more background oriented research for new projects - this is the "lab" for your compositional ideas. If you need time, space, and a group of people to experiment with delays in large spaces; if you want to study and then try just-intonation exercises with others, if you want to experiment with slow speed glissando's, or whatever else might come to mind: this workshop would give a platform for all of this.
Additional discussion will focus on theoretic texts and works by other composers relating to the research projects.

title: MUSIC_ED 422-0-1 Curriculum Development in Music Education
description_overview: The purpose of this course is to examine curriculum issues in contemporary music education and to engage in the process of curriculum development. We will consider past, present, and future trends in curriculum; reform efforts in general education and music education; and critical component areas of learning goals, sequence, and assessment.

title: MUSIC_ED 234-0-1 Double Reeds Class
description_overview: The purpose of this basic techniques class is for students to become familiar at a middle to early high school level with the oboe and bassoon. A second, and equally important purpose, is for students to learn the basics of introducing and teaching these instruments to beginning students.

title: MUSIC_ED 235-0-1 High Brass Class
description_overview: This course introduces students to the techniques and pedagogy of high brass instruments, specifically trumpet and horn. Students will complete several performance assessments on both instruments and develop materials to aid in the teaching of the instruments to beginning and intermediate musicians.

title: MUSIC_ED 401-0-1 Music and the Academy
description_evaluation_method: An individualized assessment contract will be negotiated during the first two weeks of the quarter to address the creative, pedagogical or scholarly interests of students enrolled in the class. Assignments and projects will be determined after a private conference with Professor Dobroski.;Evaluation will be based on engagement in the various course components, several book-report reviews, independent research, the presentation of students' findings to members of the seminar, and/or a final research paper on a topic related to the course subject matter (and preferably with a practical application). For example: a grant proposal, a proposal for a meeting presentation at a professional conference, an article for a publication of your choice, a teaching portfolio, etc.;There will be frequent exchanges with the instructor to insure formative and summative evaluative communication between students enrolled in the seminar, the instructor, and the guest instructors.
description_overview:
This course is an introduction and overview of music in higher education. It will also provide an introduction to professional resources and organizations for music units in colleges and universities. Emphasis will be on preparing students for a university-based career of teaching, service, research and/or creative contribution to our profession. Other emphases may include topics in administration, curricula, accreditation issues, faculty recruitment, faculty appointment and development, advancement, fund raising, alumni relations, student recruitment and admissions issues, reappointment and tenure guidelines, budget, management, accountability, personal career development, and contemporary issues facing higher education.
A major focus of the course will be to prepare each student for the variety of challenges they might face as they pursue a career in higher education. These topics could include applying for the first job, preparing for the interview, crafting a teaching presentation, preparing a teaching portfolio for a prospective employer, salary and benefits negotiations, and/or preparing for reappointment and tenure reviews.

title: MUSIC_ED 435-0-1 Selected Topics
description_overview: In this course, we will examine how the arts ecology is evolving by: critically examining selected readings; engaging with guest lecturers from the nation's leading arts foundations and government agencies; analyzing in-depth interviews with philanthropists and thought leaders; and vision-casting changes in various forms of artistic expression and music education. Furthermore, weekly group blog assignments, and bi-weekly writings will help communicate the ways your thinking is being shaped throughout the semester. The class will end with presentations where initial ideas for creative start-ups, foundation grants, or other entrepreneurial ideas will be shared and examined. Primary themes in the course include: technology, grant writing, entrepreneurship, portfolio careers, government and non-profit arts agency operations.

title: MUSIC_ED 327-0-1 Teaching Exceptional Children
description_overview: This course covers U.S. legislation relating to the education of individuals with disabilities, specific disabilities and their impact on student learning, the impact of racial, cultural, socioeconomic, gender, and neurological diversities on student learning, and accommodations, adaptations, and differentiation for the music classroom. Students engage in weekly community engaged service at a local school for children with disabilities.

title: MUSIC_ED 427-0-1 Teaching Exceptional Children
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: MUSIC_ED 362-0-1 Teaching General Music II
description_overview: In General Music II we will explore the variety of non-performance music courses in use today, by researching and discussing current literature and by experiencing hands-on activities. We will develop curricular materials for the secondary general music classroom, with a particular emphasis on the use of technology in the teaching / learning process.

title: MUSIC_ED 365-0-1 Teaching Instrumental Music II
description_overview: The purpose of this Instrumental Music II class is to introduce you to the world of secondary level instrumental music in the public schools. You will learn about managing an instrumental music program and teaching students who are are enrolled in middle school and high school band and orchestra. Your weekly teaching activities will be supplemented by intensive in-class reflection and analysis in order to develop your skills as a successful music teacher in these settings. This course is paired with a weekly MERP (Mus Ed 314) experience in the local schools working with children. At least one techniques class in string instruments and one techniques class in wind/percussion instruments is a prerequisite for this course.

title: MUSIC_ED 326-0-1 World Music Pedagogy
description_overview: This course is designed to explore the history, philosophy, and practical implementation of world music in music education settings. Students will discuss weekly readings on these topics, raising questions and making connections to their own areas of specialization. The course aims to develop in students a deeper understanding of the value of world music experiences in music education contexts and the ability to develop and implement world music activities in a variety of classroom settings.

title: MUS_TECH 259-0-1 Introduction to Music Technology
description_overview:
Registration for this class is limited. To be added to the wait list for registration, copy/paste this link and fill out the application form:

http://bit.ly/MT259-4780



Survey of music software, hardware, techniques, and tools for musicians and/or sound artists. Throughout the course, students will engage in creative work using open source and commercial music production software. Topics covered include basic acoustics, MIDI, synthesis and sampling, digital audio theory, and various other software functions. The course will culminate in the creation of an original work utilizing the techniques and aesthetic principles learned throughout the quarter.

title: MUS_TECH 321-0-1 Producing in the Virtual Studio
description_overview: The class will explore session and post-production techniques using common audio software. Software covered will include ProTools (plus plug-ins), Sound Forge, Adobe Audition, and various digital signal processing applications. Students realize projects using the software of their choice. The class will also cover accompanying hardware components. Students will complete audio projects of personal interest and pursue them with the goal of producing a professional quality result. Topics include running a hard disk multitrack session, intensive audio editing, effects processing, mastering, and basic surround mixing.

title: MUS_TECH 350-0-1 Studio Techniques for Electroacoustic Music
description_overview: Advanced individual projects in electroacoustic composition, audio programming (Max/MSP), audio engineering, or electronic instrument design. Students propose a large-scale project, which is typically developed out of previous music technology coursework.

title: MUS_THRY 318-0-1 18th Century Counterpoint
description_overview: A practical and analytic investigation of contrapuntal techniques, styles, and forms in the music of J.S. Bach, as well as his influence on Mozart and Beethoven.

title: MUS_THRY 322-0-1 Rhythm and Meter
description_evaluation_method: Paper, final: 30%;Presentations: One presentation (20%);Attendance: Class participation and attendance (20%);Class participation: Class participation and attendance (20%);Paper, mid-term: 30%;
description_overview: Among the most remarkable developments in the music theory of last decades have been the rapid advances in the study of rhythm and meter. Initially propelled by exponents of the Schenkerian theory, these advances were more recently fueled by representatives of the cognitive study of music, neo-Riemannian theory, and historical music theory, among others, and they brought about a rich inventory of analytical tools applicable to variety of musical repertoires. In this course we will review the most important theories of rhythm and meter developed in the last forty years and apply them in analysis of common-practice repertoire. This combination of theoretical inquiry and practical application of analytical methods is reflected in the course design, in which in-class discussion of readings will be followed by analytical exercises. The assessment will include preparation for and participation in the discussions, one presentation and two analytical papers.

title: MUS_THRY 436-0-1 Selected Topics in Music Cognition
description_evaluation_method: Grading: There will be a final paper of some 12-15 pages (20%), as well as daily homework (70%) and class participation (10%). Each student may take 2 ?free' absences, after which each will reduce the final grade by 5 points; this class is therefore not advisable for students who will be missing more than a few classes.
description_overview:
Motivation: This class will consider the triad music, thought, and language as a kind of puzzle: which of these two is least like the others? Typically the answer given is that music is the ?odd man out,' with thought being considered as linguistic or paralinguistic in essence. The instructor considers music as a great argument for thought being not essentially linguistic - language is then the ?odd man out.'

Content: We will take up the question of what "musical thought" is, and its relationship to visual, spatial, kinesthetic, mathematical, and linguistic cognition. Readings will come from music theory, musicology, psychology, and philosophy. No textbook is required; there are no prerequisites, but readings will present different levels of difficulty to students from different backgrounds (those with music backgrounds will find the music readings easier than the psychology ones, etc).

title: MUS_THRY 335-0-1 Selected Topics in Music Theory
description_overview: This course will approach Beethoven's Missa Solemnis and Ninth Symphony as two sides of the same coin, for reasons that begin with but extend beyond their interrelated compositional history. We will draw on perspectives from Beethoven scholarship, music theory, musicology, cultural studies, and microhistory, in order to examine the meaning of these works in their original historical and cultural contexts and the implications of those meanings for today.

title: MUS_THRY 335-0-2 Selected Topics in Music Theory
description_evaluation_method: -This is a hands-on class; your work involves daily analysis and listening.;-Grades on your daily work and class participation are crucial; keep up with the work.;-No late assignments will be accepted. ;-A 15 page final paper is required, on one or two of the pieces we will study. ;-Attendance is expected at every class meeting. I allow two "free" absences, after which each absence lowers your final grade by 5 points. ;;Grades will be given on the following basis:; Daily assignments: 50%; Class participation: 10%; Final project: 40%; Total: 100% ;;I use a 10-point grading scale in converting these numbers to letter grades. Thus:; 100-94 A 93-91 A- ; 90-88 B+ 87-84 B 83-81 B-; 80-78 C+ 77-74 C 73-71 C-; 70-68 D+ 67-64 D 63-61 D-; 60-00 F

title: MUS_THRY 450-0-1 Seminar in Music Theory & Cognition
description_overview:
This seminar will be theoretical and conceptual in orientation, bringing two ostensibly disparate discursive spheres into dialogue. The first of these is the broad realm of gender and sexuality studies known as trans or transgender studies, and the second is transformational theory, a major subfield of contemporary North American music theory since the 1990s. Theories of trans identity are highly contested, explicitly political, and culturally current. Transformational theory is largely formalist (albeit with a pronounced and seemingly paradoxical phenomenological substrate). In this seminar we will consider the ways in which these intellectually distinct areas of thought might speak to each other.

The most readily apparent common thread between the two involves a set of questions around what it means to move from one state to another?or, alternately, how the distance or space between states is to be understood. The distinction between these modalities is absolutely crucial to both areas of thought, and both theorize the distinction in explicit terms. David Lewin, who came to be understood as the founder of transformational theory, begins his seminal book "Generalized Musical Intervals and Transformations" with a simple diagram of a unidirectional arrow. Colloquially known as "Lewin's arrow," the meaning of the diagram has been widely glossed as "the interval from s to t is i," where "interval" refers to "directed measurement, distance, or motion" between any two entities (not necessarily pitches) within a defined musical "space" (Rings 2011, 12; Lewin 1987, xxix). Note the distinction between "distance" and "motion"; these concepts subsequently form the two main theoretical foundations of Lewin's approach.

Almost thirty years later, in an essay on trans identity in the "London Review of Books", Jacqueline Rose counterposes the perspective offered by trans theorist Jay Prosser, for whom the "move from A to B is a conclusive self-fashioning or it is nothing," with that of Kate Bornstein, for whom "in her new life, as for [Susan] Stryker, transsexuality is an infinite confusion of tongues" (vol. 38:9, May 2016). In trans theory, and more specifically in theories of "transition," a unidirectional arrow can represent directed motion toward a stable alignment of body and identity whose realness is absolutely crucial, while for others the line has no arrow, is infinitely divisible, or is completely unsuitable as a model.

Major questions posed by this course include the following:
? How can the diverse perspectives on transition articulated by trans theorists and activists productively destabilize certain widespread assumptions within music theory?
? What can music theory, in which "transition" is a fundamental concept in contexts ranging from the undergraduate classroom to the most rarified intellectual circles, contribute to broader discourse on the subject?

Students in the course should have an advanced understanding of music theory as a professional discipline and fluency in musical analysis. The final project will be a substantial theoretical and/or analytical paper.

title: MUSICOL 346-0-1 Composer Topics
description_overview: Scholars, critics, and concertgoers alike regularly characterize Ludwig van Beethoven as the West's, if not the world's, "greatest composer." Why? The answer lies in a complex web of issues, based partially on the unquestionable power and aesthetic appeal of Beethoven's music, but also on concepts of genius, heroism, politics, myth, and meaning in music that were shifting in the early nineteenth century. This course aims to better understand Beethoven's music by situating it within the aesthetics of the French Revolutionary period, the genres of Classicism and the new subjectivity of the nineteenth century; probing the gestural intersections between Beethoven's vocal and untexted repertoires; mapping Beethoven's expansion of music genres; exploring important performers of Beethoven's music; understanding connections between Beethoven's music and late eighteenth-century religious philosophies; and considering performance practice from the nineteenth century to today in a global context. Although it is a fairly large 300-level class, it will be run as a pro-seminar, meaning graduate-level group discussion of scholarly readings from upper level academic journals, and independent research work, is expected of all students. Students taking this course should have some background in music history and performance; some reading knowledge of German is a plus. This is a historical course, not a music theory/analysis course. This year we will also analyze the many "Beethoven 250" events happening around the world.

title: MUSICOL 335-0-1 Selected Topics
description_overview: This course will explore the issue of interpretation in music, both in theory and in practice. We will examine and compare different interpretations of classical and popular works and consider interpretation in fields such as law, acting, and cooking. We will also discuss means of interpreting historical accounts of music making. Students will be required to contribute meaningfully to class discussions, give individual presentations, and submit final projects. A central goal of the course is to develop listening and analytical skills useful in evaluating musical interpretations, and to develop a conceptual framework for crafting new interpretations of familiar works.

title: MUSICOL 443-0-1 Seminar in Music and Shakespeare
description_overview: This course offers students the opportunity to explore some of the many intersections between Shakespearean drama and music from the late sixteenth century through the early twenty-first, not only in many sorts of performance of the plays themselves, but also in opera, ballet, film, musical theatre, art-song, popular music, and the symphony, to name only a few. Textual languages include not only The Bard's original English and its more modern forms, but also French, German, Hindi, Italian, and Russian, for starters. Because the original productions of all of Shakespeare's plays included music, and each one has inspired many musical interpretations since that time, we will concentrate on three. Students will have the opportunity to work with other plays for research and/or performance projects.

title: MUSICOL 354-0-1 Topics in 19th Century Music
description_evaluation_method: Evaluation is based on attendance (10 pts.), two written assignments (worth 20 pts. each if submitted on time, worth half credit if submitted late but within one week of the due date), two 10-minute presentations in class, accompanied by a handout or a PowerPoint file (or equivalent technology) chosen independently by the students (15 pts. each) on topics approved by the instructor, and a Final Take-Home Examination (20 points) There will be no midterm in the course. Students who submit a concert report of a live musical performance which includes repertoire relevant to the course may earn up to 10 extra credit points, provided that they have secured prior permission of the instructor and agree to follow the guidelines provided for such cases.
description_overview: What does music have to do with death, dying, and traditional beliefs regarding afterlife, and in what ways can musical confront these experiences? This course will cut across boundaries of genre to explore the musical response to death in both instrumental and vocal works chosen mostly from the 19th-century repertoire, with occasional glances backward to the 18th century and forward to the 20th. Units of the course will include the Requiem Masses of Berlioz, Verdi, Dvo?ák, Fauré, and others; the frequent use of the Gregorian Dies Irae melody as a musical symbol; selected death scenes in opera; visions of the afterlife in both vocal and orchestral music; and examples drawn from the genres of "elegy" and "in memoria."

title: MUSICOL 355-0-1 Topics in 20th Century Music
description_evaluation_method: Evaluation will be based on attendance (10 pts.), two shorter written assignments (worth 20 pts. each), a research project culminating in a term paper of 8-10 pp. (worth 30 points, due for submission on the last day of class and serving in lieu of a Final Examination) on a topic approved by the instructor no later than Week 4 of the quarter, a brief oral report accompanied by a handout including bibliography, on the same topic as the research project (10 pts.), and class discussion (10 pts.). Students who submit a concert report of a live musical performance which includes repertoire relevant to the course may earn up to 10 extra credit points, provided that they have secured prior permission of the instructor and agree to follow the guidelines provided for such cases.
description_overview: Composers, performers, and musical institutions in Hitler's Germany and Stalin's Russia underwent profound and even traumatic transformations. In this course we will examine the effects of these changes on musical life from the 1920s through the aftermath of World War II. Special topics to be covered include the crackdown by the Soviet government on Sergei Prokofiev and Dmitri Shostakovich in 1936 and again in 1948, the Munich exhibit of "Entartete Musik" (Degenerate Music) in 1938, music in concentration camps, the concept of Internal Exile ("Innere Imigration"), and the controversial careers of figures such as Richard Strauss, Wilhelm Furtwängler, Herbert von Karajan, and Elizabeth Schwarzkopf.

title: BUSCOM 911-0-1 Applied AI in HealthTech
description_overview:
AI (Artificial Intelligence) has emerged as the biggest game-changer in the Healthcare Industry. In the first 3 sessions of this course, we will analyze and develop systematic frameworks to assess the business value as well as the legal, ethical and regulatory risks of the key AI-data enabled healthcare strategies-to save time, lives and money. We will cover disruptive company case examples and explain the so-called "Deep Medicine" scenarios revolutionizing the highly active venture-capital funded sectors of
? Virtual Assistants, Therapy Bots and Carebots for Elder Care
? Medical Imaging and Diagnostics
? Patient Data and Risk Analytics

The fourth and last day of the session will be a hands-on Applied AI NLP (Natural Language Processing) Chatbot Bootcamp. We will use Google Design Sprint techniques to design and prototype a mobile healthcare chatbot (Snatchbot) and then explain its value proposition and usage in a 2-3 minute video pitch (Powtoons). No coding or technical background required since we'll be using a free drag and drop mobile chatbot builder and video editor. Your team pitch and demo will be presented in class for voting and winning fun prizes.

title: BUSCOM 781-SF Competition Regulation: Antitrust and Intellectual Property
description_overview: Competition is central to the technology sector, and the laws that regulate that competition often overlap and intersect in complex ways. On the one hand, antitrust laws seek to restrict exclusionary or exploitative behavior by dominant firms and to prevent collusion among firms against their customers and consumers. On the other hand, intellectual property laws seek to incentivize innovation by creating de facto monopolies over patentable technologies and by granting other exclusive rights through the enforcement of trademarks, copyright, trade dress, and trade secrets. What happens when these systems collide? In this class, we will explore antitrust enforcement and doctrine as applied the the technology sector, examine how Silicon Valley companies seek to protect and police their intellectual property, and discuss how in-house counsel and enforcers balance the competing interests of fostering innovation while combating anti competitive and exclusionary activity.

title: BUSCOM 640-1 Finance I
description_overview:
Finance 1 covers managers' and investors' most fundamental finance decision: how to value a project or an asset. Managers must determine the value of building a factory, entering a new market, or purchasing an entire firm when deciding in which projects to invest. Similarly, individuals must assess the value of financial securities to decide how to invest their wealth. Finance 1 teaches methods for valuing projects or assets. These valuation tools lay the foundation for all work in capital markets and corporate finance. Law students will be able to better understand the decision-making of their clients, participate in the multidisciplinary teams necessary to execute complex transactions, and assess financial issues arising in litigation, regulation, and other contexts.
Prerequisites The prerequisites for this course are knowledge of probability and statistics through linear regression and accounting.

title: CONPUB 633-1 American Indian Law
description_overview:
This course provides an overview of federal Indian law, including the nature and history of the tribal <-> federal legal and political relationship, basic legal definitions within Federal Indian law (such as what is "Indian country"), canons of construction unique to Indian law, tribal sovereignty and its protection, basic questions of federal and state authority within Indian country, and tribal, federal, and state jurisdiction in Indian country according to default rules as well as special statutory regimes. Specific topics for study and analysis include the foundational doctrines of original Indian title; inherent tribal sovereignty; congressional plenary authority over American Indian affairs; and the federal trust duty to protect American Indian lands and rights. These doctrines' impact on the contemporary lives, resources, cultures, and rights of the American Indian peoples will be evaluated within selected legal frameworks.

Federal Indian law is of obvious relevance to those students with an interest in our indigenous nations and their populations. Less obvious, however, is the importance of rulings in the field for law more broadly defined. For example, Chief Justice John Marshall's opinions in the so-called Cherokee cases of the early 1800s were foundational in determining the obligation of states to abide by decisions of the Supreme Court. Further, understanding Federal Indian law is crucial for any lawyer who represents a tribe or advises investors whose capital is to be connected, even if only in a tenuous way, with a federally recognized tribe.

After covering the foundational material, this course examines in greater depth selected specialized areas such as: civil and criminal jurisdiction within Indian country; missing and murdered indigenous women; environmental law; taxation; cultural and religious freedoms; child welfare law; gaming; economic development; reserved water rights; food sovereignty; cultural sovereignty; and hunting and fishing rights. The areas to be covered will be determined early in the first half of the course.

title: CONPUB 722L-1 Comparative Law
description_evaluation_method: Assessment will be a "take-home" examination (or seminar paper). No prior knowledge of a foreign law or language is expected. Additional Course Information: Meets Perspective Elective degree requirement
description_overview: This course addresses foreign law, which matters to U.S. lawyers in international business or arbitration and is important within national law (consider a Boston contract governed by Swiss law or a Miami resident bequeathing real estate in France). Controversially, many claim that U.S. courts can rely on foreign law in adjudication. Is foreign law legitimate normative authority in the United States? Is meaningful interpretation of foreign law even possible for a U.S. lawyer or judge? How to optimize one's understanding?

title: CONPUB 660-1 Immigration Law
description_overview: This course surveys immigration and citizenship law in the United States. The core issues at stake in this course?the boundaries of political membership and the systems for managing migrant populations?play a significant role in many areas of the law and present fundamental challenges to the United States in the twenty-first century. We will examine the entry, presence, expulsion, and naturalization of noncitizens, as well as the content and significance of U.S. citizenship and nationality, from a variety of perspectives: historical and contemporary; procedural and substantive; constitutional, statutory, and regulatory. Specific topics will include the plenary power over immigration; the interaction between immigration and federalism; the constitutional rights of noncitizens; the criteria for the admission of noncitizens on a temporary or permanent basis; the grounds for exclusion and deportation; the rules governing adjustment of status; and the ongoing political debates surrounding immigration reform.

title: CONPUB 775-1 The Regulation of Money in Politics
description_evaluation_method: Grading will be based on class participation and a paper requirement. Class participation;includes serving as a discussion leader for one class. Discussion leaders are expected to open;their assigned class with a brief introduction to the readings and take more active participation in;class discussion.
description_overview:
This seminar explores the cutting-edge debates in the regulation of money in politics and
government. The readings are devoted to different perspectives on the current controversies in
the field. The goals of the seminar are development of your understanding of the emerging law
and regulation of money in politics, exposing you to some of the best scholarship in the field, and
improving your ability to evaluate and critique legal scholarship. The readings explore several
controversies in the field, rather than offer an intellectual history of the field. Although helpful,
the Election Law course is not a prerequisite for taking this seminar.

title: CONPUB 720-1 Topics in Government Secrecy
description_overview: This course introduces students to major mechanisms by which the executive branch of the federal government keeps secrets, including the classification system, the doctrines of executive privilege and state secrets privilege, and prosecuting information leakers. The course also introduces students to some of the major means through which secrecy is challenged, including congressional oversight, the Freedom of Information Act, first amendment access and news gathering claims, and whistle-blower protection laws.

title: CRIM 638-1 Criminal Justice Reform
description_evaluation_method: Grades will be based on general class participation (20%), in-class presentations (20%), and the final paper (60%).
description_overview:
The United States is at the cusp of a potentially significant period of criminal justice reform. There is an emerging consensus in both parties and all three branches of government that the criminal system is malfunctioning in ways that do profound damage to the country, but consensus stops there. On one side are those who think the root of the crisis is the American public, and the solution is to place control over the criminal system in the hands of officials and experts. On the other side are those who think the root of the crisis is a set of bureaucratic structures divorced from the American public's concerns and sense of justice, and the solution is to make criminal justice more community-focused.

This course will examine criminal justice reform from two theoretical perspectives. We will first examine the two perspectives themselves. We will then bring the two perspectives to bear on three of the major headings of the contemporary crisis: criminalization, sentencing, and plea bargaining. We will close by examining some of the major proposals for policy reform.

Course Particulars: This course is a seminar, with a heavy emphasis on reading, writing, and discussion.

title: LAWSTUDY 727-1 Federalist Papers
description_overview:
The Federalist Papers have been called the most important reflections on government ever written in America. Alexander Hamilton, James Madison, and John Jay, using the pen name "Publius," wrote the Papers in support of the ratification of the Constitution proposed by the Philadelphia Convention of 1787.

The purpose of this seminar is to conduct a close reading of the leading numbers of the Federalist Papers, paying particular attention to their historical context and their implications for later legal and political developments. We will also read and discuss some of the most prominent Anti-Federalist writers such as "Brutus" and the "Federal Farmer," since it was their writings to which "Publius" was often responding; as well as Montesquieu, whose ideas were so influential on both Federalists and Anti-Federalists. Finally, we will discuss the fascinating relationship between the two primary authors, Hamilton and Madison, who were united in this project but quickly became political enemies in the administration of President George Washington. How did this happen and with what implications for subsequent American history?

title: LAWSTUDY 924-1 Legal Technology
description_overview: Under the American Bar Association's Model Rules of Professional Conduct, attorneys are required to "keep abreast of changes in the law and its practice, including the benefits and risks associated with relevant technology." In this course, technology for law practice will be examined, with topics including, but not limited to, cloud computing, information security, artificial intelligence, data-driven lawyering, eDiscovery, and access to justice. Throughout the course, emphasis will be placed on both the ethical implications associated with the use of technologies, as well as on practical strategies for using technology in law practice. Evaluation will be based on participation during in-class discussions, a group presentation, and a final paper or hands-on project that incorporates one or more of the technologies discussed during the course.

title: LAWSTUDY 710-1 Privacy Law
description_overview: This course examines the law of information privacy: an individual's ability to control their personal information. The course examines the philosophical roots of privacy and traces the history of American privacy law, contrasting it with recent developments in Europe. We will review the major federal privacy statutes, the role of administrative agencies in regulating corporate privacy-related conduct, and the large gaps that remain in the protection of individual privacy rights. Particular attention will be paid to ongoing efforts to regulate emerging technologies such as biometrics, location tracking, and DNA databases. Evaluation will be based on a final exam.

title: LITARB 714-1 Clinic: International Human Rights Advocacy
description_evaluation_method: See course information document, which will be available at the start of the semester.
description_overview:
During Spring Semester 2020, students will work on one or more of the following projects:

1. Ethiopia Project: We will continue our work with our Ethiopian NGO partners in challenging the privately-owned Lega Dembi Gold Mine, which has poisoned the environment and devastated the lives and livelihoods of the indigenous agro-pastoral Guji people. In January and October 2019, clinic students traveled to Ethiopia to meet with our NGO partners and to interview victims, Guji elders, Ethiopian lawyers, health workers, mine employees, local university experts, and others; we may or may not return during Spring 2020 for further meetings and fact-finding. Thus far we have prepared reports to the UN Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW), the UN Human Rights Council's Universal Periodic Review mechanism, the UN Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights and the UN Special Procedures human rights complaint mechanism. Students traveled to Geneva in 2019 to participate in the CEDAW session and the UPR Pre-Session; during Spring 2020 we hope to participate in the Human Rights Council's full-day discussion of children's right to a healthy environment, including by organizing a side event during this session on the impacts on children of toxic contamination by extractive industries. We also hope to collaborate with Ethiopian attorneys on either litigation in Ethiopian courts or a complaint to the African Commission on Human and People's Rights. Students will also participate in our ongoing strategizing on how to move our advocacy work forward.

2. Migrants Rights Project: (a) The role of private security companies in the detention and other abusive treatment of migrants has elicited the concern of the UN Working Group on the Use of Mercenaries (WG), which is one of the UN Human Rights Council's Special Procedures. The WG has asked our clinic to prepare a comprehensive report on the role of private companies in the detention and other treatment of migrants fleeing, or trying to flee, across the U.S./Mexico border. The WG, which receives and responds to complaints of human rights violations relevant to their mandate, has encouraged us also to file complaints on behalf of individual migrants who are victims of human rights violations by these private security companies. This project will be a collaboration between Prof. Bridget Arimond's IHR Advocacy Clinic class and Prof. Carolyn Frazier's International Children's Rights Advocacy Clinic. Students working on this project will be involved in extensive research, interviewing, analysis and writing. It is anticipated that during Spring 2020 students working on this project will travel to one of the migrant detention centers to interview NGO advocates as well as, if possible, detained migrants themselves. (b) Students will also do research and analysis to explore the viability of a federal court class action lawsuit under the jurisdiction provided by the Alien Tort Statute, to recover damages for victims of the Trump Administration's 2018 family separation policy. If it is concluded that such a suit is viable, we will move ahead to file suit together with NGO and pro bono law firm partners.

3. LGBT Rights Project: Working in partnership with the NGO Sexual Minorities Uganda (SMUG), we will prepare a report on human rights violations based on sexual orientation and gender identity in Uganda. This may lead to additional collaborative work with SMUG, possibly including the development and implementation of training workshops for human rights defenders.

title: LITARB 700T-SF DPELC Bay Area Trip
description_overview:
The Entrepreneurship Immersion Bay Area Spring Break course is designed to expose students to the entrepreneurship ecosystem in Silicon Valley and the Bay Area. Students will spend the week of Spring Break (March 23 - March 27) in the Bay Area meeting with start-up companies, venture capital funds, private equity funds, incubators / accelerators, technology companies, venture attorneys and various other thought leaders from across the entrepreneurial spectrum.

The class will meet once prior to our week in California, and once following our return (dates and times to be determined). Our goal will be to understand how various entrepreneurial ventures are innovating in today's market and the role that law plays in fostering entrepreneurship and innovation in both early stage and larger companies.

Additionally, prior to leaving for the Bay Area each student will be assigned one company that the group will be visiting. Students will conduct research in advance of travel, and during our week in the Bay Area each student will, prior to visiting his or her company, share background information regarding such company. At the last class meeting (following our return), each student will give a short presentation to the class regarding one or more unique ways in which such student's assigned company is innovating in the marketplace. This presentation will serve as the class project for each student.

title: REG942-0-1 Energy & Climate Change: Law & Policy
description_evaluation_method: Paper, finalAttendanceClass participationSimulation / role-playWriting assignments-Student assessments will be based on (i) class participation (50%) and (ii) performance on a final project/paper (50%).;-Grading will be on a letter basis (A+ through F). Student assessments will be based on (i) engaged participation in class discussions and exercises (60%) and (ii) a final paper (40% of grade).
description_overview:
Energy is at the heart of the modern world's economic and societal progress, without which we could very well likely still be living in caves and grass huts and dying by the ripe age of 21. Energy is also at the heart of the dramatic rise in global warming and the unprecedented damage this warming is causing to our climate, our environment and our selves. This means we are faced with a challenge: how do we continue to support worldwide economic growth and the quality of life for millions it will provide, an economic growth which in large part still must be fueled by energy consumption, yet at the same time significantly reduce the global warming caused by the very GHG emissions such energy consumption has spawned and address and adapt to the adverse climate change impacts that are already baked into our climate system. This class will explore the law's role in meeting this existential challenge.

The objective of this course is to provide an overview of the major legal principles, statutes, regulations and policies applicable to the energy area; explore from a legal perspective some of the significant issues in the energy space today, with a focus on climate change; and use the intersection of energy and the law to examine the process by which our society makes major public policy, commercial and individual decisions involving complex issues of science and technology.

title: REG940-0-1 Medical Devices: Regulation & Compliance
description_overview:
This course will examine the regulation of medical devices and the interplay of statutory law, industry standards, and regulatory agency guidance. We will explore Food and Drug Administration (FDA) regulations; requirements for the development, manufacturing, and distribution of these products; and compliant interactions between industry and physicians (and other healthcare providers. We will also look at healthcare fraud and abuse, including the anti-kickback statute.

The course will cover the regulatory and compliance considerations for:

? Bringing a medical device to market for the first time
? Keeping that medical device product on the market
? Compliance considerations in the sales and marketing of medical devices
? Expanding sales and marketing of the device into other geographies

While the primary focus will be on the US to establish a foundation, the course also will provide insight to medical device regulation and compliance globally. Additionally, where appropriate, a comparison of medical devices to other regulated products such as drugs and biologics will be highlighted.

title: TAX643-1 European Union Taxation
description_overview: The objective of this course is to familiarize students with the tax rules developed at the European Union level concerning: (1) the current limits to their adoption taking into consideration the decision-making process (2) the main tax problems dealt by the European Union Court of Justice and the solutions implemented by the EU Member States (3) State Aids. A broad overview of both direct and indirect taxation will be given. Specific attention will be paid to some issues now under discussion, such as, tax transparency and whistleblowers, or green taxation and sustainable development.

title: TAX655-1 Income Taxation of Trusts and Estates
description_evaluation_method: Exam, final
description_overview: This course examines the rules of federal income taxation of trusts and their beneficiaries and grantors and decedent's estates. It covers the rules found in Subchapter J, Sections 641 through 691, of the Internal Revenue Code. Among the topics addressed will be the quasi-conduit regime of Subchapter J, simple and complex trusts, tax treatment of grantor trusts, income in respect of a decedent, and the special rules for trusts eligible to own S corporation stock, grantor retained annuity trusts, unitrusts, and split-interest charitable trusts. Sample problems illustrating the application of these rules will be used, and planning suggestions and practical considerations will be discussed.

title: TAX632-1 International Estate Planning
description_evaluation_method: Evaluation Methods: Written Paper and Presentation
description_overview: This course will examine the transfer tax, income tax, and property law issues applicable to non-resident alien individuals investing in, or residing in, the United States, and of United States persons investing or residing abroad, including residence, domicile, and situs issues; challenges faced by multi-country estates and multi-national families; expatriation and immigration issues; the income tax rules on the residence of trusts; the income taxation of foreign trusts and their beneficiaries; grantor trust rules applying to foreign and United States grantors; a comparison of trusts to comparable non-trust entities; the application of bilateral tax treaties to the nomadic client; wealth transfer planning strategies for inbound and outbound clients.

title: BMD_ENG 403-0-01 Advanced Systems Physiology
description_overview: Cellular mechanisms of and quantitative systems approach to human renal, digestive, endocrine, and metabolic physiology.

title: BMD_ENG 315-0-01 Application of Genetic Engineering to Immunochemistry
description_overview: Genetic engineering has revolutionized biological and medical sciences. The first example was the manufacturing of human insulin in bacteria. In this course, genetic engineering is applied to understand the biological, medical and engineering aspects of immunology. Immunochemistry deals with biochemical molecules of antibodies, T cell receptors for antigens, major histocompatibility complex class I and II molecules, cluster of differentiation molecules, etc. Basic mechanisms of vaccination will be analyzed using detailed differential equations, with special emphasis on influenza, HIV, and cancer.

title: BMD_ENG 348-0-1 Applications of Regenerative Engineering
description_overview: Fundamentals of human disorders; engineering aspects of regenerative medicine; application of regenerative engineering to human disease.

title: BMD_ENG 207-0-21 BME Lab: Experimental Design
description_overview: A laboratory course focusing on quantitative physiological measurements and analyses, instrument characterization, statistical design of experiments, and training in preparation and organization of laboratory notes and reports. Prerequisites: AP stats or BME 220 or IEMS 303 or ME 359.

title: BMD_ENG 207-0-22 BME Lab: Experimental Design
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: BMD_ENG 353-0-1 Bioelectronics
description_overview: Development and design of sensors, stimulators, and their medical devices for bio-integrated electronics. Materials design and fabrication of passive and active components for sensitive, multimodal, and robust wearable and implantable devices.

title: BMD_ENG 354-0-1 Bioelectronics Lab
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: BMD_ENG 446-0-1 Biomaterials in Synthetic Biology
description_overview: A course that focuses on the emerging principles in synthetic biology that have the capability to expand the functionality of biomaterials: what properties of biomaterials 'matter', emerging techniques to control the biological-material interface, and ways of inscribing the vital functions found in biological systems into synthetic materials.

title: BMD_ENG 390-3-1 Biomedical Engineering Design
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: BMD_ENG 448-0-1 Cardiovascular Protective Engineering
description_overview: Molecular basis of cardiovascular development, performance, and pathogenesis; engineering analysis of cardiovascular functions; and fundamentals of cardiovascular engineering and regeneration.

title: BMD_ENG 311-0-1 Computational Genomics
description_overview: The course introduces state-of-the-art genomic sequencing technologies and computational modeling of high-throughput sequencing datasets. Through the course, students will learn how to apply these experimental and computational genomics technologies to study gene expression regulation underlying various biological processes, such as oncogenesis. Students will also apply computational and statistical skills, using linux and R/Matlab/Python.

title: BMD_ENG 365-0-01 Control of Human Limbs and Their  Artificial Replacements
description_overview: This course considers normal human movement; pathological conditions resulting from disease, injury, malformations, birth, etc.; and engineering approaches such as prostheses (limb replacements) and orthoses (limb assists) that may be able to ameliorate the conditions and promote improved movement and function. An objective of the course is to try to bring together technical analysis and synthesis skills of students with the practical problems of persons disabled by amputation, stroke, spinal cord injury, and other causes.

title: BMD_ENG 316-0-01 Engineering Design of Therapeutic Antibodies
description_overview: Following the development of genetic engineering, protein engineering takes a step further to improve the functions of existing human proteins and enzymes by selective modification of their active sites. Therapeutic antibodies illustrate this engineering process in detail. They are approved by FDA mostly for the treatment of cancers and autoimmune diseases. Mouse antibodies are first modified by protein engineering to give rise to chimeric therapeutic antibodies. They are then further improved to produce humanized mouse therapeutic antibodies. Finally complete human therapeutic antibodies are engineered. Detailed understanding of protein folding is essential.

title: BMD_ENG 270-0-01 Fluid Mechanics
description_overview: The flow of fluids is important in many biomedical applications ranging from blood flow in the human body to drug delivery. BME 270 provides a general introduction to fluid mechanics, both statics and dynamics. The laboratory component of the class consists of take-home experiments using aquarium pumps.

title: BMD_ENG 512-0-01 Graduate Research Seminar in Biomedical Engineering
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: BMD_ENG 271-0-20 Introduction to Biomechanics
description_overview: The objective of this course is to provide BME undergraduate students with concepts and skills required to develop an ability to visualize and understand the fundamental behavior of structures and solids. Students will learn methods of computing stresses in several types of structural and machine components and the fundamental approach for determining internal forces and stresses in indeterminate structures - use of equations of equilibrium, force-temperature-deformation relations, and expressions for the geometry of the deformations. This will be accomplished in a series of lectures taught by a CIV instructor. In a weekly discussion section lead by a BME instructor, students will apply that knowledge to biological and physiological systems.

title: BMD_ENG 380-0-01 Medical Devices, Disease & Global Health
description_overview: An examination of the intersection of technology and the delivery of health care in resource-poor environments, especially in Africa.

title: BMD_ENG 462-0-1 Neural Engineering:  Sensory Acquisition through Movement

title: BMD_ENG 307-0-01 Quantitative Experimentation and Design
description_overview: The objective of this course is to provide BME undergraduate students with skills required to design experiments, conduct measurements, and analyze the resulting data. This will be accomplished using a series of lectures and four laboratory modules concerning quantitative physiology, physiological measurement techniques, instrument design, and statistical design of experiments.

title: BMD_ENG 303-0-01 Quantitative Systems Physiology

title: ENTREP 325-0-1 Engineering Entrepreneurship
description_overview: Engineering Entrepreneurship teaches students how to identify a problem and build a business solving that problem. Centered in the Jobs-To-Be-Done framework, students will learn how to create solutions based on the pain points of consumers. In small groups, teams will test their prototyped solutions in various markets. ENTREP 325 is cross-listed with IEMS 325 and is a core course for the Undergraduate Minor in Entrepreneurship.

title: ENTREP 331-0-1 Entrepreneurial Sales and Marketing
description_evaluation_method: Papers
description_overview: In Entrepreneurial Sales & Marketing, students will learn about the tools and strategies startups use to generate revenue. With a focus on data, students will explore Google Analytics, selling, lead generation, inbound traffic, content, SEO, public relations, paid search and social media while working with teams and honing presentation skills. Entrepreneurial Sales and Marketing is a core course for the Undergraduate Minor in Entrepreneurship.

title: ENTREP 361-0-1 Entrepreneurship Demystified
description_evaluation_method: Group projectPresentationsClass participationPapersProject, final
description_overview:
You've heard the inspiring founder stories and tales of the fortunes to be made. In this class, we'll explore another side of entrepreneurship. Through case studies, readings, guest speakers, and thoughtful discussion, we'll probe the ethical, social, and ecological implications of building a company in the 21st century. We'll take an unflinching look at current events in the startup world and interrogate how business intersects with the major social issues of our time - including privacy, gender discrimination, racial justice, mental health, income inequality, and climate collapse. Students are expected to participate actively in weekly discussions and openly reflect on their own career experiences and goals in the context of the issues discussed in class.

**This course satisfies a core requirement for the entrepreneurship minor.

title: ENTREP 360-0-1 Leadership, Ethics, and You
description_overview:
COURSE SYNOPSIS: What exactly is leadership? Are leaders born? Are you a leader? Where do ethics, and integrity fit into leadership, and even more importantly into your life? Leading others is hard. Leading oneself is even harder. This course is designed to dig into these questions to help you develop your "True North," a compass that will help you lead yourself (and others), with your values, on your terms, to your destination.

This course satisfies a core requirement for the entrepreneurship minor.

title: ENTREP 475-0-1 NUvention: Analytics
description_overview: NUvention: Analytics is a unique interdisciplinary course designed to create opportunities for students to create new analytics technologies and then build businesses around their innovations. This one-quarter class is conceived by students within the Engineering, Business, Law, Communications and other schools across campus along with the assistance of an Advisory board and the Farley Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation. The course is built around projects, so an advisory board will keep track of the projects, giving its expert advice in order to ensure a proper product-market alignment.

title: ENTREP 476-0-1 NUvention: Arts
description_evaluation_method: Group projectPresentationsClass participationGroup workPapersProject, final
description_overview:
NUvention: Arts targets students from across Northwestern with a passion for the arts. Our hope is to facilitate the creation, innovation, and organization of new ideas and companies in the field of creative arts. The goal of this course is to help students understand that success in the arts is a function of passion, work ethic, talent, and entrepreneurial drive. Those applying for this class should share a desire to learn about and/or desire to start a company in the creative arts.

In the past twenty years, digital disruption has upended many industries including the music, film, and television, and has erased most of the barriers to entry in those industries. Furthermore, the transparency of the Internet has shifted the power from large corporations to anyone who has a great idea, talent, and Internet connectivity. Digital technology allows artists to have greater control over their careers and enables entrepreneurs to create new companies that disrupt the traditional way of doing things.

title: ENTREP 473-2-1 NUvention: Web and Media
description_overview: NUvention Web+ Media focuses on all web-based businesses. Project areas include Mobile Applications, including for social media, New Media, Social Gaming, eCommerce/Deals, Analytics, Cloud, Big Data or ideas from students in the program.

title: ENTREP 225-0-1 Principles of Entrepreneurship
description_evaluation_method: Group projectClass participationPapersProject, final
description_overview: Principles of Entrepreneurship is designed for students with limited or no prior exposure to entrepreneurship. In this course, students will learn the basics of starting a company, and will also learn to analyze other ventures through a variety of frameworks. This includes learning about customer discovery, finance, and marketing. This course is cross-listed as IEMS 225 and is a core course for the Undergraduate Minor in Entrepreneurship.

title: ENTREP 225-0-2 Principles of Entrepreneurship
description_overview: Principles of Entrepreneurship is designed for students with limited or no prior exposure to entrepreneurship. In this course, students will learn the basics of starting a company, and will also learn to analyze other ventures through a variety of frameworks. This includes learning about customer discovery, finance, and marketing. This course is cross-listed as IEMS 225 and is a core course for the Undergraduate Minor in Entrepreneurship.

title: ENTREP 395-0-1 Special Topics
description_evaluation_method: PresentationsClass participationExamsProject, final
description_overview:
SPECIAL TOPICS COURSE: ENTREPRENEURIAL ENDURANCE & MINDSET

Entrepreneurs are constantly sharing ideas, soliciting feedback, asking for help, recruiting stakeholders, identifying talent, pitching investors and pursuing customers. Entrepreneurial selling isn't just a set of skills or a process - it is the #1 job of an entrepreneur. But, before we can effectively sell or build a team, we need to learn how to fearlessly ask, navigate tough conversations, manage through adversity, build networks of support, quickly reframe failure as data for future decision-making, and prioritize time and other resources. At the end of 11 weeks, you will walk out of this class with the tools and mindsets to succeed and flourish in your future careers - whether that's starting your own business, working at a Fortune 500 company, a nonprofit, or anything in between.This course satisfies the "experiential course" requirement for the Undergraduate Minor in Entrepreneurship.

title: ENTREP 395-0-2 Special Topics
description_evaluation_method: PresentationsClass participationPapersProject, final
description_overview:
LAUNCHING YOUR BRAND

This is the Farley Center's capstone course in our "creative entrepreneurship" track. In this course, you will learn practical tools to launch your career as a working artist, performer, musician, or creative entrepreneur. You will learn: the fundamentals of developing a "portfolio" approach to your career and securing multiple income streams, the basics of personal finance, how to navigate intellectual property issues, how to leverage a strong personal brand, and how to develop and maintain a high-value professional network. This course will be highly individualized, and in addition to in-class learning, students will be expected to meet with mentors from the Northwestern alumni network. Students will draw on foundational learning from either ENTREP 310 - Growing and Monetizing your Fanbase AND/OR ENTREP 311 - Storytelling for Business. This course satisfies the "experiential course" requirement for the Undergraduate Minor in Entrepreneurship.

title: ENTREP 395-0-3 Special Topics
topic: Startup Finance for the Gig Economy
description_overview:
SPECIAL TOPICS COURSE: STARTUP FINANCE FOR THE GIG ECONOMY

Startup Finance for the Gig Economy will appeal to students that are in the freelancing industry or looking to start a small business. With an introduction to financial literacy that focuses on the ability to manage personal finance matters efficient, it includes the knowledge and skills to manage financial resources, such as budgeting, accounting, tax planning, forecasting and valuation. This course satisfies the core accounting/finance requirement for the Undergraduate Minor in Entrepreneurship.

title: ENTREP 395-0-4 Special Topics
description_overview:
SPECIAL TOPICS COURSE: MAKE YOUR STARTUP MARKET READY

COURSE SYNOPSIS: "The world is full of ideas. I suspect you are too. How many ideas have you had? Tens, hundreds, thousands? Let's agree on "many." How many of those ideas have your pursued to completion? Would "few to none" be a fair answer? This is just the human condition.

Are you working on an idea with a team currently? Are you committed to seeing it through? Then this is the class for you. It will provide the structure and discipline to see your idea to a conclusion. An idea that does not pan out is not failure. Not trying is failure." If your team wants to make significant progress on your business in 10 weeks, this is the class for you.

This course satisfies the "experiential course" requirement for the Undergraduate Minor in Entrepreneurship.

title: ENTREP 395-0-5 Special Topics
description_overview:
SPECIAL TOPICS COURSE: CONSULTING FOR WEARABLE TECH

Consulting for Wearable Tech is a one quarter course offered to advanced undergrad and grad level students from across the campus. Students work in multi disciplinary teams to consult with client companies in the Biosensor space to explore innovative business models and research market applications for various technologies in this space. Students will learn the basics of consulting practice and the basics of lean startup methodology as well as market research techniques, strategy and tools that are then applied and integrated into a final presentation describing the findings and recommendations to the client. The industrial clients supporting this course have some predefined new technology/market opportunities for new-to-the-world products they would like to explore with the student teams, and all work product from the course will belong to the client as a result. Students will be able to demonstrate their skills in applying lean startup and business model canvas techniques to a new technology/market opportunity while working in multidisciplinary teams and working with a real industrial client under typical time constraints found in industry.

This course satisfies the "experiential course" requirement for the entrepreneurship minor.

title: IEMS 395-0-1 Special Topics in Industrial Engineering
description_overview:
This course examines whole-brain thinking and leading. Students will draw upon previous work and leadership experience to identify their own thinking and leading preferences and those of team members. Students will examine contrasting thinking and leading styles in an effort to appreciate and combine these to produce optimal outcomes.
A number of leadership theories and ways of leading will be examined including creative and agile leadership. Analytical thinkers/leaders will be challenged to spend more time with innovation and creativity, while creative thinkers/leaders will be presented with opportunities to engage in analytical problem-solving.
This course is a MS elective for Industrial Engineering.
LEARNING OBJECTIVES
? Examine and understand thinking and leading preferences for self and team
? Understand how to lead contrasting thinking and leading preferences
? Appreciate the development of creative leadership, take risks, take action, challenge the process, and push to new opportunities
? Apply the components of agile leadership- self-awareness, mental agility, people agility, change agility and results agility.
? Appreciate the need for leading throughout the organization
? Develop as people leaders, enabling others to act, inspiring a shared vision, and strengthening others while creating a spirit of community.
TOPICS
? Whole-brain thinking/leading
? Creativity, problem solving, idea generation
? Agile leadership
? Emotional intelligence
? Entrepreneurial thinking/leading
? Values Based Leadership
? Leading through coaching
