title: 311-0-21 Media Presentation: Magazine
description_overview: This course will help students develop the fundamental editing skills required of an entry-level magazine editor working on print, digital and mobile platforms. Central themes of the class include finding potential stories, establishing narrative structure, focusing language, framing and pitching ideas, and guiding writers.?Students will gain insight into the magazine business and hone the analytic discipline useful for a variety of career paths within media or without.?

title: 475-0-20 Medill Justice Project
description_overview:
For generations, investigative reporting has proven to be one of the highest and most impactful forms of journalism. It sheds light on wrongdoing, exposes rampant incompetence and calls to account powerful people and institutions, from presidents to banks to schools. Over two quarters, you will focus on social justice reporting - exploring some of the policies, programs and public and private agencies that promise to provide a safety net to tens of millions of vulnerable Americans. You will study budgets, court cases, crime logs and government institutions, do interviews with powerbrokers and the constituents they are supposed to serve, probe critical data and trends and ultimately produce a groundbreaking investigative story from the ground up.

You are expected to work regularly outside of class. You will make cold calls, dig for information and cultivate sources and investigative findings.Consider your classmates team members and allies. Consider your instructor a collaborator, editor and guide.

Investigative reporting is hard. Expect to confront roadblocks and anticipate spinning your wheels. But along the way, you will learn to think, research and write like an investigative reporter. If you are successful, your work could potentially make a difference in the lives vulnerable people from coast to coast.

title: 201-2-20 Multimedia Storytelling
description_overview: This course continues on the strong foundation created in JOUR 201-1 and significantly expands the base of multi-platform tools needed for effective, relevant and engaging storytelling for specific audiences. Instructors will guide students in the continued development of reporting, interviewing, writing and researching with a more sophisticated audience understanding using text, audio, video and photos for print, broadcast and the Web.

title: 472-0-20 Narrative Structure in Storytelling
description_overview: Narrative Structure in Storytelling is an immersive five weeks in the art of crafting stories for different media. Students will deconstruct, analyze, tear apart and re-shape stories in an effort to understand how good stories come to be. Each week the course will focus on a different medium, from narrative writing, to documentary film, to podcasts, to advertising messages and more, and identify the core components of storytelling and how that medium uses them well (think characters, leads, arc, plot, audio, etc.). Students will look at what all stories have in common as well as how mediums differ along with core tenets and when to break the rules. By the end of the five weeks, students should have a strong understanding of how to take a large body of information, organize it and then create meaningful, gripping narratives across mediums. Guest speakers may include NPR reporters, documentary filmmakers, digital editors, advertising creatives and long-form writers. Assignments include heavy reading, watching and listening to the year's best works, weekly story analyses, writing short narratives and possibly editing and reimagining stories across mediums.

title: 472-0-21 Narrative Structure in Storytelling
description_overview: Narrative Structure in Storytelling is an immersive five weeks in the art of crafting stories for different media. Students will deconstruct, analyze, tear apart and re-shape stories in an effort to understand how good stories come to be. Each week the course will focus on a different medium, from narrative writing, to documentary film, to podcasts, to advertising messages and more, and identify the core components of storytelling and how that medium uses them well (think characters, leads, arc, plot, audio, etc.). Students will look at what all stories have in common as well as how mediums differ along with core tenets and when to break the rules. By the end of the five weeks, students should have a strong understanding of how to take a large body of information, organize it and then create meaningful, gripping narratives across mediums. Guest speakers may include NPR reporters, documentary filmmakers, digital editors, advertising creatives and long-form writers. Assignments include heavy reading, watching and listening to the year's best works, weekly story analyses, writing short narratives and possibly editing and reimagining stories across mediums.

title: 479-0-20 Personal Narrative
description_overview: This five-week class is an introduction to effective and moving personal narrative storytelling. We will explore the complexity of memory and read, listen and analyze first-person pieces in an effort to help us find our own voices. Students will learn and practice pitching and producing stories, essays and multimedia pieces that incorporate reporting, experience, emotion, perspective and other important elements. Students will write/produce at least one piece targeted for a specific publication, website or broadcast audience.

title: 202-0-20 Philosophy of Modern Journalism
description_overview: This course focuses on the evolving relationship between today's news media landscape and its consumers. Students learn fundamental theories of human behavior and media consumption in order to understand new technologies, content opportunities, and relationship-building with journalism audiences. The course discusses various frameworks for thinking about the rapidly changing journalism industry, as well as the intellectual tools for students to adjust and lead as the industry changes in the future.

title: 408-0-20 Photojournalism
description_overview: Photojournalists are reporters who communicate through pictures, and students will learn to think visually in order to create compelling, storytelling images. Photojournalism has the power to reveal the human experience, and this in-depth course will give students an additional tool in their reporting skill set. Discussions of historical and contemporary photojournalism, as well as ethics in photojournalism, will accompany weekly assignments and critiques. Students will also learn to edit pictures thoughtfully to enhance the power, nuance and clarity of the story. Medill cameras are provided for use in this class, and students will receive instruction on manual controls to attain a variety of photographic effects. Upon completion of this course, students will be comfortable approaching people and documenting a variety of news and feature stories.

title: 422-2-20 Politics, Policy, and Foreign Affairs Reporting Project
description_overview: Students will delve deep into a particular politics and foreign affairs issue through an intensive multimedia reporting project on the subject. The reporting likely will include some travel. Students work closely with the instructors as well as professional media partners. It is the capstone for Medill's Politics, Policy and Foreign Affairs Journalism Specialization.

title: 201-1-20 Reporting & Writing
description_overview: This course emphasizes the critical practices of ethical journalism and deadline reporting and writing and builds a strong foundation for all Medill classes. It introduces students to the essentials of accurate journalism regardless of platform or storytelling format. Special attention is given to news and information gathering (including sourcing, interviewing techniques and practices of inclusion and sensitivity), writing, grammar, AP Style, fact checking, ethical decision-making and media analysis. The course also introduces students to a wide range of story types and career paths in media.

title: 390-0-20 Special Topics
description_overview: This course is a dive into the world of sports journalism and how sports reporters do their jobs on a daily basis, utilizing all the fundamentals of good journalism while recognizing that it is also a unique endeavor. In this class, you will learn how best to perform on deadline in the fast-paced environment of covering sports; how to craft daily game stories and features while also recognizing the importance and best use of social media as it pertains to sports journalism; how the most successful journalists in the business develop sources and report breaking news before their competition; and how to interview and interact with athletes and coaches in a way that gets the best results.

title: 390-0-22 Special Topics
description_overview: Advanced Photojournalism is recommended for students who are already familiar with DSLR cameras and have some experience using Lightroom/Photoshop. This class will review basic DSLR usage (Canon 80D), how to use Lightroom, composition, photojournalism ethics, but will primarily be a production and editing course centered around the creation of a story-driven character-based photo story. Students will pitch a photo essay project in week three and then will spend the rest of the course photographing these subjects to create the final project. Students will be expected to spend significant time with subjects gaining trust and access to tell their story. Emphasis will be placed on submitting the final projects for publication by professional journalism outlets, awards, etc.

title: 390-0-23 Special Topics
description_overview: This seminar examines the changes and challenges shaping the state of press freedom around the world today. Journalists confront increasing legal, political and physical attacks, yet are also producing landmark stories exposing corruption, abuse of power and exploitation. They face efforts by political leaders to delegitimize the "fake" media and use existing or new laws and regulations to diminish their traditional watchdog role. Turbulent social media platforms present another threat, with news organizations caught in the crosshairs of controversies arising from distorted or invented content on the Internet. The press freedom landscapes of many nations, including the U.S., contain different and common threads of rising hostility toward the media, but journalists are finding new ways, including cooperation across borders, to stand against it.

title: 390-0-25 Special Topics
description_overview: This course is designed to extend the lessons of foundational classes in narrative structure, reporting, feature storytelling, and magazine writing. The class, taught by the former editor of a national magazine, provides an opportunity to take a project already begun to the next level, with an eye toward publication. Perhaps you have a project from a reporting class, draft of a story you completed in another course, or an idea you developed during your junior- year residency program that you've been yearning to complete. Too often, the quarter system leaves promising work unfinished and unpolished. This is a new course created in order to allow you to re-report, revise, and prepare that work for submission. Taught in workshop style, using excellent contemporary narrative work as models, we'll create an environment for students who want to take the next step. The intention is to provide space and inspiration for you to take a run at producing a piece of journalism representing a capstone for your college portfolio. Online and multimedia projects welcome.

title: 390-0-26 Special Topics
description_overview: Investigative reporting holds a critical role in democracy: It sheds light on secrets and lies, exposes government malfeasance, tracks wrongdoing by lawmakers, corporate executives and power brokers and separates fact from fiction. Investigative reporting has changed broken laws, put corrupt politicians behind bars and brought down a president. In this course, we'll focus on the basics of investigative reporting that you can apply to any reporting course, as well as prepare for advanced investigative courses if you so choose. We'll explore the history, ethics, challenges and successes of investigative reporting and learn the tools used by top investigative reporters.

title: 390-0-27 Special Topics
description_overview:
This course expands the understanding of journalism beyond your own country's borders and experiences to examine the historical development, values and practices across regions throughout the world.

We explore how fundamental differences in cultural, political and economic factors led to diverse journalism models and expectations within societies. The findings are critical for understanding and evaluating how journalism is practiced in a digital age across national and regional borders.

title: 390-0-29 Special Topics
description_overview:
This class is for students who want to enhance their producing and reporting skills, especially for TV, Cable and Streaming audiences. Using CNN's Newsource and reporting in the field students will improve their writing, producing and execution/presentation skills for programs ranging from nightly news, cable politics and morning shows.

The course will include anchoring, field reporting or interviewing from the field, finding the right voice when tracking stories, doing stand-ups, live-shots/cross talk, and on-camera interviews. We will move our stories from broadcast/cable to the web and social media formats. Other topics of will include different writing styles depending on the types of news that is being reported. Body language, both as a presenter and as an interviewer. How to read your subjects body language and what they may be conveying when you are talking to them. We will also discuss current trends in the business and how to brand yourselves as you move into the job market.

Students are expected to follow local, state, national and international news and to find and produce original stories or interviews for the Chicago news market. You will be graded on how thoroughly you organize and execute your productions. The final exam will consist of a 30-minute news magazine style production that can include both in-depth magazine style stories or in-depth-interviews done in the field, by Skype or the studio.

The course will meet twice a week in the McCormick Foundation studio for three hours.

title: 480-0-20 Special Topics
description_overview: In this course students gain the ability to analyze, interpret, recognize, appreciate and understand the messages conveyed in a visual format as well as the ability to create images with a clear message. These skills are increasingly valuable in a visually stimulated society no matter what field of study. "Visual literacy is based on the idea that pictures can be ?read' and that meaning can be communicated through a process of reading." I like to think of this as opportunity to learn how to see.

title: 480-0-21 Special Topics
description_overview: In this course students gain the ability to analyze, interpret, recognize, appreciate and understand the messages conveyed in a visual format as well as the ability to create images with a clear message. These skills are increasingly valuable in a visually stimulated society no matter what field of study. "Visual literacy is based on the idea that pictures can be ?read' and that meaning can be communicated through a process of reading." I like to think of this as opportunity to learn how to see.

title: 490-0-23 Special Topics
description_overview: Student completes an original reporting project that clearly demonstrates proficiency with journalism skills taught in preceding quarters, demonstrates the quality and quantity of work appropriate to the academic credit awarded for a master's project and is worthy of being the centerpiece of a professional portfolio. The project can be in whatever medium is appropriate (or multiple media). It may be a single story, or a group of related stories. Team projects are possible, but the per-person volume of work/involvement would not lessen. Faculty will remain open to suitable creative ideas that do not fall into the category described here.

title: 490-0-24 Special Topics
description_overview:
The goal for each student in this course is to develop a distinctive voice that stands out from the cacophony of opinions in the sporting world, to create commentary that is informative, thought-provoking and entertaining and to adapt those messages for delivery across multiple media platforms: ?the written word, television, radio, podcasts and social media.

Sports are more than just home runs and touchdowns. Collectively, they're part of a $200 billion industry. And within this realm all of the elements of our society are displayed: heroism and failure, racial harmony and discrimination, drugs, religion and crime. That's why it's so important to be aware of and capable of weighing in on all current issues, not just the latest sports results.

Students will learn to coalesce their observations, opinions and experiences into compelling arguments that reflect the essence of the sports column: "I'm right, and this is why."

title: 490-0-25 Special Topics
description_overview: In this course, students will receive instruction and hands-on practice in investigative practices including filing FOIAs, obtaining and analyzing public documents, finding and understanding data, backgrounding sources, covering courts, investigative interviews and developing investigative stories. Students will hear from guest speakers about their investigative work and will visit public offices. Investigative work done in this class may contribute to students' Masters projects. Assignments will relate to practicing different investigative techniques and will not involve completed stories, though extra mentorship is available to utilize the techniques for stories if the student chooses.

title: 490-0-26 Special Topics
description_overview:
Back in the day, journalists focused on finding and telling great stories. It was someone else's job - say, the marketing or circulation department - to figure out how to reach and build the audience for the journalists' work. No more - we now need journalists to work in the emerging field of "audience development." That's the focus of our class: learning how to build an engaged audience to support and strengthen a sustainable business model. You will learn how digital publications reach and engage audiences, how web audience measurement systems work and which measurements are most useful to publishers. You will also gain practical experience using Web analytics by serving as audience consultants for a real digital publication. Students will gain a deeper understanding of the art and science of audience development, the ways publishers envision and measure their audiences, and the factors that contribute to building a successful media business.

In this course, you will:

Build your understanding of audience measurement and the behavior of digital audiences

Recognize which analytics are most useful for measuring engagement with online content

Gain an understanding of different approaches for building audience engagement

Build proficiency in digital audience analytics tools by using what you've learned to recommend better audience-engagement strategies for a real digital publication.

Learn about how audience engagement contributes to the business models that support media

title: 490-0-27 Special Topics
description_overview: Podcasting is changing the face ? and form ? of today's journalism. This class is designed for fans of narrative podcasts who have a lot of passion, but little to no practical experience in audio. You'll learn not only how to plan, record, edit, and mix audio, but also how to find and shape the kinds of stories that you love so much on This American Life, Code Switch, The Daily, and other reporting-based shows, and how to produce them in your own voice.

title: 490-0-28 Special Topics
description_overview: In this class, multidisciplinary teams of design and journalism students will imagine and prototype new approaches to local journalism. The big picture issue being addressed is that without robust local news, citizens will not have the information they need for their everyday lives about their community's government institutions, schools, businesses and neighbors. This is the second of a two-quarter sequence. Enrollment in the first quarter is not required. Students will begin from a research brief and concept developed in the previous quarter. In this class students will refine the concept and will be primarily concerned with user-experience and user-interface concerns. Students will build and test prototypes for the concept. They will test, iterate and refine those designs over the course of the quarter leading to a final UX/UI design artifact.

title: 490-0-29 Special Topics
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: 403-0-20 Sports Marketing
description_overview: Sports Marketing provides an in-depth look at concepts and methods in marketing communications for brands within the sports environment. Sports marketing includes topics such as acquisition and retention of fans, celebrity management, event execution, crisis interventions, sponsorship and partnerships, ticket pricing, social media and digital innovation, tie-ins between teams and retail, and understanding the business of sports. Students will develop an understanding of how marketing works in sports through readings, guest lectures, case analysis and discussions. The course will have a television client building an audience and guest speakers. The course will help students understand how to make decisions in ambiguous marketing environments and understand more about the business of sports. If you are not a sports lover, then the marketing aspects may appeal so that you are well versed in areas of marketing that are helpful in many fields.

title: 321-0-20 Storytelling: Magazine & Feature Writing
description_overview: This course introduces students to feature and magazine storytelling and explores different writing techniques. Students will examine and deconstruct high-concept pieces and non-fiction narrative stories from various media outlets. The class will discuss audience understanding, idea development, pitching and in-depth reporting. Students will report and produce short and long-form stories, as well as review and workshop thier pieces. The course aims to challenge students to deliver memorable works of narrative storytelling and inspire them to continue their growth as reporters and writers.

title: 413-0-20 TV News Producing and Performance
description_overview: This course is designed to give students news producing, interviewing and anchoring experience. You will learn how to "line produce" a traditional newscast with specialized software that television newsrooms use. In addition, you will get in-depth interviewing experience in the context of field and show producing. Excellent and ethical writing and editing will continue to be emphasized through the use of timely CNN footage.

title: 413-0-21 TV News Producing and Performance
description_overview: This course is designed to give students news producing, interviewing and anchoring experience. You will learn how to "line produce" a traditional newscast with specialized software that television newsrooms use. In addition, you will get in-depth interviewing experience in the context of field and show producing. Excellent and ethical writing and editing will continue to be emphasized through the use of timely CNN footage.

title: 343-0-20 The Googlization of America
description_overview: ive tech companies ? Google, Facebook, Amazon, Apple, and Microsoft ? have become the central players in the American media and cultural landscape, determining what news and information citizens consume as well as what products they buy. In this course students use recent books, news stories, and other reportage to understand how these enterprises are changing journalism, the media business, and democracy itself. Readings, research and writing assignments, group exercises in and outside class, and guest speakers.

title: 438-2-20 Washington DC Practicum
description_overview: Two days a week of advanced journalism training at sites such as Military Times newspapers, USA Today, NPR Digital, SBNation, National Law Journal, etc.

title: 438-2-21 Washington DC Practicum
description_overview: Two days a week of research and observation at sites such as the ACLU, Street Law, the Cato Institute, Center for War and Peace, State Department, Canadian (or other) embassy, etc.

title: CMN 340-0-20 Internship
description_evaluation_method: Weekly response papers, informational interview write-ups, initial and final reflection papers, resume and Linked in assignments, class participation.
description_overview:
This course is intended to provide academic structure and guidance for professional internships. Students will meet weekly with the instructor and the other interns to connect their internship experiences to academic knowledge and broader career aspirations. We will do this as a class through sharing progress reports, questions, and concerns about work at various media-related jobs. Because these internships are linked to the students' academic progress, critical reflection on these work experiences is a necessity. Students are encouraged to explore the links and gaps between what they have learned in their classes and what they are learning in the workplace.

Note: interested students must secure an internship and submit an application through the EPICS office by the appropriate deadline to be enrolled in the course.

title: CMN 340-0-40 Internship
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: CMN 380-7-20 Junior Tutorial
description_evaluation_method: Performance/Participation 20%;Listening Quizzes (4) 40%;Performance Papers (4) 20%;Listening Final 20%
description_overview: This course is an in-depth study of the music and lyrics of Stephen Sondheim. Through in-class solo and group performances, listening assignments, and style comparison papers, the class will expand the student's knowledge of Sondheim's prolific catalog. All performances will be work-shopped on vocal technique and performance practice. The focus of this course is not audition technique, but rather establishing an in-depth knowledge of Sondheim's work.

title: CMN 380-7-21 Junior Tutorial
description_overview: The first weeks are spent finding the right monologues for each student. We will search for 8 for each actor. After that the pieces are memorized and then worked on for presentation with the instructor. Each student will turn in a resume. A professional director will come in to look at the student's pieces.

title: CMN 380-7-22 Junior Tutorial
topic: Perf./Dramatic Lang of George Bernard Shaw
description_evaluation_method: Punctuation and Attendance Mandatory;Grades determined by attendance, class participation, written assignment and final performance.
description_overview:
This junior tutorial will explore Shaw's verbal stagecraft. How his use of dramatic rhetoric enabled him to convey his complex political ideas in a theatrical form in plays that continue to delight and entertain audiences today. This tutorial will focus on Shaw's own views on the actor's vocal craft using his writings and the recollections of professional actors and directors who worked with him. Students will work on the vocal rhetoric of Shaw's theatrical language through selected scenes and speeches from a variety of Shaw plays to explore how actors today can acquire the vocal ability to perform his work with skill and
professionalism.

The class will culminate in a performance of excerpts from scenes by George Bernard Shaw worked on in class for an invited audience at Northwestern.

title: COMM_ST 394-0-20 Communication Studies Research Seminar
description_overview: Adolescents coming of age in today's media-saturated world may be the most enthusiastic consumers of media. On the one hand, there are several potential benefits of media use in this developmental stage; meeting like-minded people, expressing oneself, etc. However, parents, educators, and experts are also concerned about the negative consequences associated with adolescents' use of media; associations with poor health, online bullying, etc. In this course, students will consider the wide spectrum of potential outcomes and develop their own argument about adolescents and media through the practice of reading (and writing) research on the topic. Throughout the quarter, students will explore media effects on adolescent friendships, romantic relationships, health, well-being, and more through weekly reading and writing exercises. At the end of the course, students will complete a fifteen- to twenty-page final paper on the topic of their choice.

title: COMM_ST 394-0-21 Communication Studies Research Seminar
description_overview: This writing seminar will inspire students to think about the nonprofit sector, social movements and advocacy, and organization theories by drawing upon recent environmental issues. Students will formulate their research ideas and think critically about social movements and advocacy and use this class to write and present their thoughts in a research paper. The class will be geared towards developing writing, presentation, and peer-editing skills.

title: COMM_ST 394-0-22 Communication Studies Research Seminar
description_overview: This course explores how digital media has changed our writing practices and teaches students how to analyze and compose digital and multimodal texts. At the heart of this investigation is the concept of authorship, and how automation is transforming how we communicate with one another. In this course, we will connect contemporary scholarship on automation with digital writing theories, methods, and exercises. Each week, we will practice writing various types of digital texts (e.g., blogs, encyclopedia entries, news articles, and websites) and, over the course of 10 weeks, develop a 20-page research paper that explores the complex relationship between user-generated and automated content. We will approach the practice of digital writing and the topic of automation as a collaborative process, making ample time for peer reviews and group discussion.

title: COMM_ST 394-0-23 Communication Studies Research Seminar
topic: Designing Technologies for Health and Wellbeing
description_overview:
We are increasingly using technologies for our health and wellbeing. Whether it's pulling up the notes app at the doctor's office, keeping track of daily step counts, or talking to a chatbot when feeling sad, these technologies continue to impact our daily life. In this course, we will explore how to design technologies that support humans in understanding, tracking, and managing their health and wellbeing.

This course will serve as an overview of the human-centered design process. Students will learn how to identify opportunities for interventions, recognize ethical challenges, gather user needs, translate needs into prototypes, and evaluate interventions. The course will be organized by modules, where each module represents a stage of the design process. Class activities will include a combination of lectures and discussions of relevant readings about digital health and wellbeing that correspond to the stage of the design process covered during that module. In parallel, students will follow the design process for their own digital health and wellbeing intervention. As the weeks progress, students will build upon their work and present their projects to the rest of the class at the end of the quarter.

title: COMM_ST 159-0-20 Computing Everywhere
description_overview: This course teaches computing literacy to non-technical undergraduate students.

title: COMM_ST 159-0-21 Computing Everywhere
description_overview: This course teaches computing literacy to non-technical undergraduate students.

title: COMM_ST 416-0-20 Contemporary Rhetorical Analysis
description_overview: Rhetorical analysis is a creative, pluralistic art. In this course we will investigate contemporary rhetorical analysis in two parallel ways. First, through assigned readings and class discussions, we will survey theories and practices of rhetorical analysis in the discipline of communication. We will read analytic works and discuss the perspective that scholars take in studying their chosen subjects. Second, through independent research projects, students will undertake the practice of rhetorical analysis for themselves. The class readings and the independent projects should inform one another; the readings should assist students in inventing their own perspectives and approaches, and students' ongoing independent projects should illuminate class discussion. Students who successfully complete this course should expect to be conversant in the disciplinary vocabularies of contemporary rhetorical analysis and should expect to have produced a critical work appropriate for conference or journal submission and/or for a thesis or dissertation chapter.

title: COMM_ST 370-0-20 Ethnographies of Culture
description_overview:
"How do elite chefs come up with new recipes? What makes blues authentic? What makes a model successful? What is the difference between art and craft? How does an amateur learn glassblowing? Why do people still flock to the opera house? How does a museum store an installation? Is there a career for hip-hop street artists? What kind of job is being a tour guide? Do record studio interns ever get a job? Why do we get the news that we get? And why should we care about all this?
This course looks at ethnographies of artistic practice to better understand how culture is made, circulated, and received in social life. Aiming to go beyond the personal idiosyncrasies of individual artists and media players, it shows through a myriad of studies in cultural production, what are the factors that play the greatest role in shaping contemporary cultural production: is it about professional traditions, forms of ownership and funding, government regulations, organizational factors or the social dynamics in the interplay between owners, workers, and audiences? Sorting out the factors that shape cultural production can best be accomplished via comparative research - across geographical regions, and institutional fields. This course offers a theoretical and methodological roadmap to such a project, helping students navigate through the landscape of how contemporary culture is produced."

title: COMM_ST 388-0-20 Internet and Society
description_overview: This course explores the evolution of digital media and its effects on self and society, with a focus on the historical shift away from one-way mass media toward more customized, participatory digital media. Through readings, blogging, class discussion and a final project, students are encouraged to think broadly about how digital communication technologies are impacting politics, media, business and culture and what this means for us at the individual and societal level.

title: COMM_ST 344-0-20 Interpersonal Conflict
description_overview: "This course is focused on processes observed in interpersonal disputes. Causes of conflict and methods of resolution will be discussed. Sources of information will include research and theory drawn from communication, social psychology, sociology, and organizational behavior. The course will include general models of conflict as well as material related to disagreements in specific contexts such as friendship, dating, and marriage. The primary method of teaching will be lecture and students are encouraged to ask questions and offer examples"

title: COMM_ST 246-0-20 Intro to Health Communication
description_overview: People who understand communication are uniquely positioned to solve health related problems, and their services are increasingly in demand. As such, this course is designed to familiarize you with the theory and research on communication in health and illness contexts, focusing on how messages from interpersonal, organizational, cultural, and media sources affect health beliefs and behaviors. We will explore communication in health care delivery, health care organizations, as well as health promotion and disease prevention. By taking this course, you will become a more mindful, educated, and effective health communicator.

title: COMM_ST 274-0-20 Power in Entertainment
description_overview: This course examines how power is created, sustained and challenged in entertainment media. Students will learn how and why individuals, groups and corporations achieve and maintain dominance in art, film, television, gaming and digital and social media. Particular attention will be paid to how industries have survived the digital transition. Readings will explore contemporary case studies and debates. Lectures will give theoretical and historical context. This course is intended as an introduction to creative industries and first in a sequence before "Contemporary Television."

title: COMM_ST 525-0-20 Seminar-Problems in Comm Studies
description_overview: This course is constructed as an inquiry into the origins and history of the intellectual and political project that later came to be called "cultural studies." We will consider the historical conditions of possibility that led to the intellectual and political work that first gave rise to the creation of the Birmingham Centre for Contemporary Cultural Studies and the early scholarship emanating from within it. This will necessitate close attention to post-war intellectual work in Britain, to the work of Raymond Williams, Richard Hoggart, and Stuart Hall, and to the various critiques of their work emerging out of feminist, post-colonial, and critical race theory circles.

title: COMM_ST 352-0-20 Social Network Analysis
description_overview: Use of social network analysis to understand the growing connectivity and complexity in the world around us on different scales, ranging from small groups to the web. How we create social, economic, and technological networks; how these networks enable and constrain our attitudes and behavior.

title: COMM_ST 250-0-20 Team Leadership and Decision Making
description_overview: Theories and research relating to communication in small groups and group decision making.

title: COMM_ST 360-0-20 Theories of Organizational Communication
description_overview: This course is designed to make the student aware of major theoretical perspectives of organizational communication. The student will be expected to exhibit understanding and retention of key concepts and theories. As such, the primary course content will come from social scientific theory and research. We will explore general perspectives of organizational processes as well as those focused on particular organizational problems.

title: COMM_ST 205-0-20 Theories of Persuasion
description_overview: This course provides a general introduction to the social-scientific study of persuasive communication. The course focuses on alternative theoretical accounts of the processes underlying persuasion and on research findings concerning the effects of various factors on persuasive effectiveness.

title: COMM_ST 395-0-20 Topics in Communication Studies
description_overview: The course examines the effects of mass media on individuals and groups in society. Media content and effects are explored in various domains, including politics, violence, pornography, health, science, video games, as well as pro-social and environmental news media. The course begins with a historical overview of theory, methodology and research in the realm of media effects. The course continues with extensive survey of contemporary research about the role of media in facilitating changes in people and society, and consideration of possible explanations of how media effects occur. The course will conclude with discussion of possible ways to diminish socially undesirable media effects.

title: COMM_ST 395-0-24 Topics in Communication Studies
description_overview: This course will examine the relationship between social media, technology, and mental health. Students will explore and critically analyze social media platforms (Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, YouTube, and blogs) and technology (apps, online therapy, video games) used to address mental health concerns. Conversely, students will scrutinize social media?Äôs and technology?Äôs impact on mental health and wellness, with special attention paid to topics such as social comparison and online self-presentation.

title: COMM_ST 395-0-25 Topics in Communication Studies
description_overview: In today's organizations, personality tests are often used to improve communication and relationships among employees. This course will provide an overview of research exploring how personality affects interpersonal communication in organizational contexts. Topics will include the influence of personality on social networks, leadership, and team processes, as well as the value and application of personality assessments in the workplace. Students will reflect on and integrate popular press pieces and scholarly journal articles.

title: COMM_ST 395-0-26 Topics in Communication Studies
description_overview: Please note: students who have completed Comm_St 352: Social Network Analysis will not receive credit for this course. Introduction to Social Network Analysis is intended to lay down the foundations of network-thinking, and connect that with various topics of social sciences. It will not stick to any substantive area of inquiry or to any specific methodology, rather, it will give a broad map of substantive questions and approaches to answer them. As a consequence, actors and relations will be defined in many different ways ranging from friends and families, to groups, to companies, to social media and beyond. This class will teach you to see the world in a new way: using a network perspective. Together, we will examine how we create social, professional, and technological networks, and how these networks influence our behaviors, beliefs, and opportunities. The new theoretical concepts will be implemented using the statistical software R. No previous programming experience is required: familiarity with R and the relevant packages will be slowly built up through the course; however, an open mind, patience and willingness to make some intellectual effort will be key for this endeavor to be successful.

title: DANCE 326-0-20 Advanced Improvisation
description_evaluation_method: Designing and leading improvisation;Performance critiques;Performance
description_overview:
The course explores the diverse objectives of Dance Improvisation for performance. Through rigorous movement laboratories, students will explore the process and role of improvisation in performance. The work is grounded in readings and class discussion. Topics include but are not limited to site specific work, contact, use of text, collaboration, and music. Designing and leading improvisations are also be covered.

Prereq: Dance 101-3

title: DANCE 170-0-20 Ballet I
description_overview: This course is designed to provide students with basic vocabulary and to learn the proper execution of the steps of the classical technique. This course is designed to challenge the student both physically and intellectually.

title: DANCE 270-0-20 Ballet II
description_overview: This course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to continue more advanced classical ballet with an emphasis on technical development. It is an extension of level one, emphasizing more intricate movement combinations, including the integration of vocabulary, concepts of dynamics, attack, musicality, alignment, lines, use of space, and artistry, while challenging the student physically and intellectually.

title: DANCE 235-0-20 Choreography for Musical Theatre
description_overview: Musical Theatre choreography. 3 goals are addressed. First, reviewing how to manipulate the concepts of space, time and energy in short movement studies. Second, creating a movement study in dramatic action that relies on manipulations of space, time and energy. Third, choreographing a short dance to music on other dancers using the preveious movement studies as guideposts.

title: DANCE 360-0-20 Jazz III
description_evaluation_method: Each class unit lasts 2 weeks, during which material will be explored and added. You will be videotaped at the end of each unit. This video will be available for online viewing, only to the class.
description_overview:
Jazz III is structured with technical exercises that begin class, exploring a range of Jazz movement and music styles, incorporating Modern principles of weight, fall and recovery, grounding, and release. Longer movement passages fusing technique with a range of stylized movement addressing turns, floor work, extensions and jumps complete the class.

The emphasis is on focus; specifically bringing the focus to transitions, and the idea that all mo(ve)ments are transitional. Transitions micro and macro, we use the micro lens of the focus on the local/personal movement/moment to affect not only the larger technical concept being addressed, but the global/spatial movement patterns and the performative aspect as well. We will address the idea of performing without grafting on any additional frameworks outside of spatial concepts, letting the clarity and truth of the movement concept project itself, finding the humanity in abstraction. Using total commitment to presence in the fully embodied execution of the moment at hand by integrating the ideas of total presence in repetition of learned material, and use of improvisation in technical exercises to infuse the material with vital energy and urgency, and aid in keeping the focus on the now.

title: DANCE 250-0-20 Modern II
description_overview: This class is a level 2 technique class, designed to deepen the potential for expression in the moving body. Uniting function and expression using weight, space, time and intention, students will infuse personal, idiosyncratic, and technical movement with urgency, vitality and humanity, while exploring inner and outer focus to bridge improvised and re-membered movement.

title: DANCE 350-0-1 Modern III
description_overview: Modern III classes will incorporate fundamentals of Modern Dance Technique and draw on foundational concepts from iconic choreographers such as Martha Graham, Doris Humphrey, Lester Horton, and Jose Limon and their evolution through the artistic filters of modern masters like Paul Taylor, Merce Cunningham, and Mark Morris. Focusing on dance's deeply-rooted connection to music and rhythm both qualitatively and dynamically, students will perform a daily warm up designed to enhance alignment, build core strength, increase somatic awareness. and move through to more extended movement sequences to challenge students' capacity to delve deeply into complex phrases and cultivate artistic autonomy. In Modern III we shall also explore compositional concepts utilizing longer repertory phrases throughout the semester to hone critical thinking, foster problem-solving skills, and increase the students' general understanding of dancing with others.

title: DANCE 150-0-20 Modern l
description_overview: This course will explore basic Contemporary and Modern Dance under the umbrella of Martha Graham, Katherine Dunham, Merce Cunningham and Garth Fagan technique, some of the historical context from which it developed, and is currently performed.

title: DANCE 130-2-20 Music Theatre Dance I
description_overview:
The intent of the Musical Theatre Dance class is to further the skill set used in auditioning for and working within the context of the Musical Theater world by utilizing original choreography from shows chosen for their range of styles, in combination with technical exercises.

Smaller passages of movement, either original or in the style of the show will be combined with technical exercises in the Center in the beginning of class.

Longer movement passages will be used across the floor following the center exercises.

The vocabulary learned will be combined into a longer sequence at the end of class, employing staging and simple choreographic conventions.

Each class unit lasts 2 weeks, during which material will be explored and added. You will be videotaped at the end of each two week unit. This video will be available for online viewing, only to the class.

title: DANCE 395-3-20 Senior Seminar
description_overview:
The course is for graduating seniors pursuing the dance major and is intended to mentor the senior concert as well as prepare for entry into the professional world. The seminar provides opportunities for students to explore issues related to this important transition.


This class is offered in the Spring Quarter for one full credit. However, students must be enrolled in Fall and Winter for no credit.

title: HLTH_COM 430-0-1 Changing Health Behavior
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: HLTH_COM 440-0-1 Engaging Patient in Healthcare
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: HLTH_COM 479-0-3 Health Information Technology for Communication, Coordination and Integration
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: HLTH_COM 401-0-3 Professional Skills for International Students
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: MSLCE 550-0-1 Culture and Globalization
description_overview: What is globalization? And how does it affect cultural production? How is it that the cultural products of some countries circulate easier than others? What is the relationship between place and cultural industries? What makes a city a cultural capital? And how is it that cities compete via culture to appropriate economic capital? This course will address these and other questions through an engagement with scholarship on a range of creative industries including fashion, television, music, movies, fine arts, and the high-end food industry. The course is designed to provide a historical and theoretical introduction to the intersection between globalization and cultural production and to allow students to apply that knowledge to a range of contexts.

title: MSLCE 545-0-1 Entrepreneurship in the Creative Industries
description_overview:
NUvention: Arts consists of ten classes, each in a three-hour session, created to help facilitate the creation, innovation, and organization of new ideas and companies in the field of the creative arts. The goal of this course is to help students understand that success in the arts is a function of passion, work ethic, talent, and entrepreneurial drive; and culminates in a term project that will help translate ideas into potential products or services related to the arts. While we will spend time studying traditional media companies involved in the arts, the goal of the course is to fuel the students' passion to become entrepreneurs in the arts and start a company.

This course is cross-listed with ENTREP476. MSLCE students taking the NUvention: Arts course will be enrolled in this course number by the program.

title: MSLCE 540-0-1 Leading Creative Teams
description_overview:
This course provides fundamental tools from the behavioral and social sciences that will improve students' ability to analyze organizational dynamics and to take robust action. More specifically, students will develop their leadership skill-set and toolbox of strategies to be effective leaders of creative industries in general and teams in particular. Leveraging a combination of theory and practice, a hand-on applied teaching style will be used to prepare students to be able to support and lead high-performing, creative teams and firms.

In the spring 2020 quarter, this class will meet on five (5) Mondays only throughout the quarter: April 6, April 20, April 27, May 18 (9am-4pm), and June 1 (9am-1pm).

title: MSLCE 472-0-1 Marketing Strategies in Creative Industries
description_overview: Marketing plays a crucial role in the success of creative enterprises. Without the engagement of customers, the creative product remains unappreciated and unfunded. Marketing a creative enterprise requires as much time, attention and toil as the core creative product, itself. It requires a blend of art and science: an appreciation for the fundamentals of consumer-centered marketing with an understanding of the special requirements of the creative enterprise itself. MSLCE 472 will introduce students to the most contemporary thinking related to consumer-centered marketing, known as IMC. The course is intentionally designed to blend theory with application both inside and outside of the classroom.

title: MSLCE 580-0-3 Professional Development
description_overview: This elective provides an opportunity for MSLCE students to craft their own career development plan and execute that plan through the completion of a customized course comprised of professional development, industry-based learning activities, and reflection assignments. To earn course credit, students are required to attend and actively participate in the equivalent of 15.0 hours of activity comprised of a combination of events and sessions organized by MSLCE, School of Communication/EPICS Office, or other approved activities. This includes, but is not limited to, speaker events, site visits, career sessions, external networking events, informational interviews, and coaching. Students will also have the opportunity to reflect on their activities, efforts, and the insights they gain that are most germane to their own professional development through written assignments and the development of a career action plan. Note: This course does not have regular class meetings. All course communication and documentation will be maintained through the course Canvas site.

title: MSLCE 529-0-27 Special Topics in Creative Enterprises
description_overview:
This course is structured as a seminar, providing a learning environment devoted to i. exploring current issues in, or affecting, creative enterprises and ii. solutions to address them. Concerns about the lack of racial diversity and the varied perspectives on how to address those concerns are prominent matters within arts and cultural sectors. Therefore, the Spring 2020 seminar is focused on matters relating to racial diversity, inclusion and equity within arts and entertainment.

The seminar will be comprised of reflective discussion on course materials, insights shared by guest speakers, and personal insights. Ultimately, this course will help students deepen their understanding of racial diversity, inclusion and equity within the arts and entertainment sectors, and their insights on ways to address racism within these sectors at the organizational- and systems-levels. Grades are based on class participation, a series of short written reflections, and a final independent project in the form of a paper or podcast.

title: MSLCE 525-0-1 Understanding Media Markets: Users, Makers, and Metrics
description_overview: Digital media create a marketplace where an endless number of options compete for a limited supply of public attention - an environment where building audiences is a prerequisite for making money or exercising influence. This course explains how the preferences and habits of media users, the strategies and constraints of media makers, and the growing prevalence of data and metrics form a dynamic marketplace that shapes public attention. Topics include theories of media choice, the role of social networks, sharing economies, audience-making strategies, bias in measurement, recommender systems, big data, audience fragmentation, and the marketplace of ideas.
