title: MTS 525-0-20 Special Topics Research Seminar
description_overview: This course takes up issues concerning evidence-based general claims about message effects. It addresses the design and analysis of primary research (e.g., case-category confounds, NHST and its discontents, the "replication crisis") and the pursuit of research synthesis through meta-analysis.

title: MTS 525-0-21 Special Topics Research Seminar
description_overview:
"How do elite chefs come up with new recipes? What makes blues authentic? What makes a model successful? What is the difference between art and craft? How does an amateur learn glassblowing? Why do people still flock to the opera house? How does a museum store an installation? Is there a career for hip-hop street artists? What kind of job is being a tour guide? Do record studio interns ever get a job? Why do we get the news that we get? And why should we care about all this?
This course looks at ethnographies of artistic practice to better understand how culture is made, circulated, and received in social life. Aiming to go beyond the personal idiosyncrasies of individual artists and media players, it shows through a myriad of studies in cultural production, what are the factors that play the greatest role in shaping contemporary cultural production: is it about professional traditions, forms of ownership and funding, government regulations, organizational factors or the social dynamics in the interplay between owners, workers, and audiences? Sorting out the factors that shape cultural production can best be accomplished via comparative research - across geographical regions, and institutional fields. This course offers a theoretical and methodological roadmap to such a project, helping students navigate through the landscape of how contemporary culture is produced."

title: MTS 525-0-22 Special Topics Research Seminar
description_overview: The course examines the effects of mass media on individuals and groups in society. Media content and effects are explored in various domains, including politics, violence, pornography, health, science, video games, as well as pro-social and environmental news media. The course begins with a historical overview of theory, methodology and research in the realm of media effects. The course continues with extensive survey of contemporary research about the role of media in facilitating changes in people and society, and consideration of possible explanations of how media effects occur. The course will conclude with discussion of possible ways to diminish socially undesirable media effects.

title: PERF_ST 103-0-20 Analysis & Performance of Literature
description_overview:
Overview of class

The course studies the performance of poetry, short fiction, and non-fiction. It explores how performance helps the performer and audience to understand a text; it considers in what ways a performance can "match" a written text; and it examines the techniques of performance. Students write three critical papers and give three live, graded performances. There are some quizzes and workshops. The class is neither an acting class nor an English class, but it draws on practices fundamental to both. Much of class time will be devoted to performance of texts and rigorous critical discussion of the performances and the works on which they are based. Consequently, attendance is mandatory. It examines the role of the audience in the critical reception of the text. The course is designed for both students with little prior performance experience and those with considerable theatrical experience.

It is an excellent course for students to take who want to become excellent communicators; it hones your professional skills and gives you the poise and confidence to excel in the "real world."

title: PERF_ST 326-1-20 Performance Art
description_overview:
This is an introduction to the history and practice of performance art. Drawing on myths, fairy tales, dreams and music, students will create three solo performances and collaborate in the creation of two group performances, all with specific criteria and parameters. Students will write short papers on each other's performances and a term paper. There will be a mid-term as well on the readings and classwork up to that point. The course is designed to tease out the elements of theatricality within performance: sound, light, image and movement; and to practice attending to performance in a highly detailed and focus way in order to understand how performance deploys these elements to create feeling, meaning and the ineffable.

Note: no electronic devices are allowed in class unless they are part of a performance.

title: PERF_ST 203-0-20 Performance Culture and Communication
description_overview: The course asks the question: How are stories and storytelling central to our lives and to human communication? We will explore how storytelling performances reflect our families, communities, culture, and nation. To engage the power and significance of storytelling performance we will focus on three units: (1) Oral Narrative. Students will learn how to conduct in-depth interviews, on a particular topic, to gather oral narratives and their meanings from specific family, friends, or community members. (2) Myth. Students will read and discuss ancient and contemporary myths to unravel deeper questions about local and global experiences. (3) News Reports. Through guided instruction students will select a current news story, from electronic or newspaper journalism, they feel reveals an urgent issue they are compelled to share. Each of the three units will culminate in a performance: a solo performance of an oral narrative, a group performance of a myth and, finally, a multi-media group performance of a news story. The course is highly interactive and performance based. The unifying thread and overarching question for the course is: How does storytelling performance and creative communication help us better engage and illuminate our world and the world of others, e.g., identity, family, community, nation, social relations, political institutions and economic orders?

title: PERF_ST 210-1-20 Performance of Poetry
description_overview:
Course Description and Purpose: To introduce students to a wide range of poetic voices and styles with a concentration on prosody; to cultivate the ability to attend to dense and sometimes complicated text with pleasure; to improve our ability to see, describe and respond to performance in a specific, astute and empathetic way; to bring to consciousness the relationship between form and content, image and idea; to develop performance skills and to engender or amplify a life-long love of poetry that may be of aid in the darkest hours.

Course requirements: Two short performances and one recital; a brief paper, a final paper, a scan of a poem, and a mid-term on prosody; two ungraded tasks (leading discussion on a poem and handing in a paragraph describing your recital); consistent class attendance and participation; reading of all assigned and performed poems.

Note: no electronic devices allowed in the classroom unless they are part of a performance.

title: PERF_ST 119-0-20 Production Laboratory
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: PERF_ST 515-0-20 Seminar: Problems in Performance Studies
description_overview:
This course offers an introduction to theoretical debates on the engagement of performance as focus, critical framework, and as technique in curatorial practice as well as a practical workshop on the protocols of exhibition and programming development around contemporary performance. We will consider curation broadly to include the development of contemporary performance (theatre, dance, performance art) in museum and gallery settings and formal performance spaces. We will also engage more traditional exhibition contexts where the presentation of objects (artistic or otherwise) or the engagement with audiences (in art institutions or elsewhere) are conceptualized or intervened by means of performance. Through a series of case studies and site visits, workshops, and critical discussions and writing tasks, students will develop broad knowledge of the field as well as an individual curatorial project proposal.

The class requires three site visits outside of the regular course schedule which will be arranged as group experiences.

title: PERF_ST 515-0-21 Seminar: Problems in Performance Studies
description_overview: In this course, we will investigate the role of the body in the emerging field of Queer African Studies. Looking to performance, visual art, film, and literature, students will consider what it means to engage African studies through a queer optic, and examine how queerness has been discussed, theorized and articulated via the "African" body.

title: PERF_ST 515-0-22 Seminar: Problems in Performance Studies
description_overview: SoulWork is a comprehensive method for making performance that includes acting, singing, directing, writing, ensemble-building and community engagement. Created by Dr. Cristal Chanelle Truscott from generations-old principles of African American performance traditions, SoulWork aims to create opportunities for connection and social and creative power for communities across race, class, gender and spiritual identity. SoulWork's practical techniques will be explored through an interactive blend of discussion, readings/viewings, workshops and training in SoulWork technique and participation in an ensemble performance sharing at the end of the course. This course will focus on an introduction to SoulWork's key principles of Cultural Conservatory, Call/Invitation, Living in Call & Response, Emotional Availability and Unending Climax. Students will be encouraged to bring the fullness of their identities to this practice - to investigate the creative power of culturally-specific and culturally-aware artistic methods/processes, to explore socially-conscious engagement with devising texts and ensemble-building, and to rehearse and perform with emotional flexibility and spontaneity.

title: PERF_ST 330-0-20 Topics in Performance Studies
description_overview: What is folklore and how have we come to understand it in relation to the idea of the nation? What have been the contributions and interventions by queer and trans populations in redefining nationalistic and gendered ideas of folklore? This course serves as an introduction to the study of folklore with a particular emphasis on the ways expressions of gender and sexual non-normativity have challenged heteronormative views of folklore as an ideology and narrative. Students will explore works from Folklore Studies and Queer Studies side by side to allow for the unusual conversation between these two fields. Particularly, students will develop skills in textual, visual, performance, and ethnographic analysis, which will enable them to theorize and define folklore in new ways. By exploring a wide range of performance practices such as patron-saint festivals, dance, carnivals, rituals, music, oral traditions, and performance and visual art, we will examine how concepts such as tradition, religion, race and ethnicity, class, authenticity, and indigeneity have played important roles in defining folkloric practices as such. In this sense, we will ask how queerness is represented but also serves as an optic to look at folklore in more expansive and inclusive manners. Students will engage in written assignments, autoethnographic exercises, and a short performance project. Although we will engage our conversations hemispherically and globally, most of the case studies will focus on folklore in the Americas. No previous performance experience or knowledge of Spanish and Portuguese are required.

title: PERF_ST 330-0-21 Topics in Performance Studies
description_overview: SoulWork is a comprehensive method for making performance that includes acting, singing, directing, writing, ensemble-building and community engagement. Created by Dr. Cristal Chanelle Truscott from generations-old principles of African American performance traditions, SoulWork aims to create opportunities for connection and social and creative power for communities across race, class, gender and spiritual identity. SoulWork's practical techniques will be explored through an interactive blend of discussion, readings/viewings, workshops and training in SoulWork technique and participation in an ensemble performance sharing at the end of the course. This course will focus on an introduction to SoulWork's key principles of Cultural Conservatory, Call/Invitation, Living in Call & Response, Emotional Availability and Unending Climax. Students will be encouraged to bring the fullness of their identities to this practice - to investigate the creative power of culturally-specific and culturally-aware artistic methods/processes, to explore socially-conscious engagement with devising texts and ensemble-building, and to rehearse and perform with emotional flexibility and spontaneity.

title: PERF_ST 330-0-22 Topics in Performance Studies
description_overview: This course offers an introduction to theoretical debates on the engagement of performance as focus, critical framework, and as technique in curatorial practice as well as a practical workshop on the protocols of exhibition and programming development around contemporary performance. We will consider curation broadly to include the development of contemporary performance (theatre, dance, performance art) in museum and gallery settings and formal performance spaces. We will also engage more traditional exhibition contexts where the presentation of objects (artistic or otherwise) or the engagement with audiences (in art institutions or elsewhere) are conceptualized or intervened by means of performance. Through a series of case studies and site visits, workshops, and critical discussions and writing tasks, students will develop broad knowledge of the field as well as an individual curatorial project proposal.

title: RTVF 464-0-20 Advanced Media Writing
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 443-0-20 Advanced Seminar in Film & Video
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 411-0-1 Cultural History of Television
description_overview: This course explores of the cultural, political, and aesthetic history of television. We will especially concentrate on US TV's "classic three network" period from the 1950s-1980s and trace changes in the medium up through TV's convergence with digital/streaming media. The class also considers broader theoretical and methodological questions about media history and culture more generally, and we explore the history of alternative television/video as well as TV on mainstream venues. Although the focus is on US TV, students may will write seminar papers on any national/transnational television system, and may also write about contemporary TV through a historical perspective.

title: RTVF 392-0-20 Documentary Production
description_evaluation_method: Still image assignment: 5 points;Soundscape project: 5 points;Pitch and written proposal: 10 points;Rough cut: 20 points ;Final Documentary: 40 points;Attendance, participation, various written exercises, professionalism: 20 points
description_overview: In this course, students will examine documentary practices and produce their own 6 to 8 minute short. The emphasis will be on watching and workshopping what students generate, as well as screening and discussing clips from a diverse array of filmmakers. Class participants will consider: What trends are cutting-edge in non-fiction filmmaking, and in what ways are these trends influencing the field? How can stylistic choice underscore content? Why do ethical considerations become paramount for many documentarians? How can filmmakers influence society, and what types of tools increase impact? What are the traditional versus alternative/emerging possibilities for financing and viewership?

title: RTVF 372-0-20 Editing
description_overview: Editing is considered by many to be the critical artistic expression of filmmaking; on par with dialogue, cinematography, even writing. In this class, you will take crucial steps towards your evolution as an editor of the moving image. We will do this by reading and discussing critical editing concepts, including the basic editing stages, practices and terminology. We will discuss how and why these different elements work to further the story and develop the vision of a film. We will watch also films and the discuss techniques employed, seeing the concepts we've discussed appear in film and analyzing their effectiveness. And, of course, you will be working extensively with hands-on editing in Adobe Premiere on several excercises and one main project: you will work with uncut footage provided by the instructor to increase your creative analysis and develop your own style and voice as an editor.

title: RTVF 326-0-20 Film & TV Criticism
description_overview: As described by critic Mark Fischer, "Capitalist Realism" describes "the widespread sense that not only is capitalism the only viable political and economic system, but also that it is now impossible even to imagine a coherent alternative to it." This course examines contemporary literature and cinema that addresses the styles and themes of "capitalist realism" as an aesthetic, as well as the affective dimensions of neo-liberal culture.

title: RTVF 260-0-20 Foundations of Screenwriting
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 260-0-21 Foundations of Screenwriting
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 260-0-22 Foundations of Screenwriting
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 566-0-20 Full-length Project III
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 312-2-20 History of Film II
description_evaluation_method: Class/Discussion Section participation, Team presentations, Final Project
description_overview: This course will attempt to account for major theoretical, industrial, aesthetic, and political developments in international postwar cinema. Contemporary and historical texts will be presented and discussed in class sessions to inform an understanding of critical issues in the evolution of narrative cinema from 1948-2000. Films from Alfred Hitchcock, Jean-Luc Godard, Agnes Varda, and Barbara Kopple, among others, will be screened. Readings include essays from Andre Bazin, Linda Williams, bell hooks, and Peter Wollen.

title: RTVF 553-0-20 Interactive Techniques/Emerging Forms
description_overview: This course is a workshop that will explore the intersection between new media production and documentary practice. The course will approach interactive documentary as an emerging field. Students will study the history and theory of interactive documentary while actively contributing to field as it develops. The course will focus on unique aesthetics and affordances of documentary narratives when expressed through hypertext, interactive video, video gaming, as well as other hybrid genres. Students will develop their own interactive documentary projects with special attention to web publication. Students will be evaluated through active participation, individual exercises, reading responses, presentations, and projects in group critique. The course is designed for students with no prior experience working with digital tools, but who are prepared to engage their own documentary practice with new media techniques at a graduate level.

title: RTVF 368-1-20 Introduction to Acting for the Screen
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 384-0-20 Introduction to Sound Postproduction
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 380-0-20 Lighting and Cinematography
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 190-0-20 Media Construction
description_evaluation_method: Projects will be evaluated on technical achievement (videography, sound, editing, lighting, and production design) as well as their ability to convey narrative. There will also be written and practical exams.
description_overview: Students will be introduced to the technical and theoretical components necessary for media construction: narrative, sound, image, and editing. Projects will include audio and video exercises and will culminate in the production of group short films.

title: RTVF 190-0-21 Media Construction
description_overview: Through lectures, reading assignments, discussions, in-class screenings, and in-class workshops, this course provides a supportive environment where students are encouraged to take risks and experiment as they discover their narrative voice. Students will have opportunities to work both individually and primarily, collaboratively, in small groups. Students will be introduced to the technical and theoretical components necessary for media construction: narrative, sound, image, and editing. Projects will include audio and video assignments and will culminate in the production of group short films.

title: RTVF 351-0-20 National Cinema
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 351-0-21 National Cinema
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 322-0-20 Radio/Television/Film Genre
description_evaluation_method: Attendance-participation; Notes on weekly reading assignments; short assignments to devise a final unit; two take-home essays.
description_overview: This class considers the pleasures and perils of the romantic comedy, organized in short units that highlight specific aspects of the genre. The first two units focus on common narrative devices that make the genre less than benign: deception and competition between women. The third unit considers a group of films that are barely rom-coms even as they conclude in the formation of romantic couples. We consider whether these ex-centric variations offer any respite from the perils of deceit and competitiveness. The final unit will be student-generated. (Time will be allotted within the class period for groups to meet, develop a short unit; half-way through the quarter, different proposals will be shared with the class which will, as a group, decide what the final unit will be.)

title: RTVF 321-0-20 Radio/Tv/Film Authorship
description_evaluation_method: Students will be assessed through: 1) a portfolio of short response papers; 2) three short videographic essays made using Adobe Premiere and clips from Lynch's oeuvre; 3) in-class reading quizzes; 4) a short critical review of the new "Twin Peaks" VR experience,
description_overview:
We know very well that media texts are collaborative projects: when we see the credits roll at the end of a major film for example, we see hundreds of names and numerous specialized tasks. And yet the idea of an individual creator still has a powerful hold over the way most of us think about and experience the media. What does it mean to be an "author" in the creative industries? What is the nature of creative work? How are artistic reputations constructed and understood? What role do critics and audiences play in that process? Why some media texts have authors and others don't? How does collaboration work in the creative industries? In this course we will investigate these and other questions through the analysis of the transmedia career of David Lynch.

Lynch's output covers a remarkably wide range of production contexts and media forms, encompassing visual art, film, television, photography, furniture design, popular music, online films, digital cinematography, and virtual reality. Lynch can be seen as the ultimate crossover artist: a cult filmmaker who went on to have a hit network television series ("Twin Peaks") the same year as winning the Golden Palm at the Cannes Film Festival. Starting his career as a painter, he emerged as an avant-garde filmmaker in the early 1970s. After his first feature Eraserhead achieved the status of a cult classic on the "midnight movie" circuit, Lynch jumped into mainstream filmmaking, and has become one of the rare directors to find success with general audiences, cult fans, and academics. Films such as Blue Velvet became touchstones for film theorists during the 1980s, and are still discussed in academic circles today. Lynch has never been without his critics, and his work has come under fire for its depiction of women, sexual violence, race, and class. Lynch has often had creative control over his projects, and yet his distinctive "Lynchian" signature was forged through long-standing collaborative relationships with a cohort of actors, composers, editors, and sound designers. Lynch is thus a remarkably fertile case study for a consideration of media authorship, modes of collaboration in the creative industries, the history of film culture since the 1970s, the various logics of film, television, and digital media, the importance of sound design in audio-visual media, the representation of race, class, and gender, and a range of other issues.

title: RTVF 479-0-20 Seminar: Studies in Film and Video Prod
description_overview: In this seminar, first year MFA in Documentary Media students will build the foundation for their thesis project, which can either be a 10-20 min film or an interactive/new media project that they will complete during their second year of study. Students will generate ideas, delve into research, and explore various methods of approach for their project. Modeled after the pre-production phase of professionally produced documentaries, the course will guide students in developing a verbal pitch, written proposal, and work sample. Students will also learn about different film funding sources and how to envision their projects' potential audience and impact.

title: RTVF 298-0-21 Studies in Media Topics
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 398-0-20 Symposium: Issues in RTVF
description_overview: This seminar examines the historical association between media and ghosts. We will examine both the "haunted" qualities of various media (radio, television, computers, etc) as well as the representation of haunted spaces through the media. Individual topics include seance technologies, movie ghosts, paranormal reality television, and digital discorporation.

title: RTVF 556-0-20 Thesis 3
description_evaluation_method: Class participation, in class presentations, assignments, participation in event planning, and completed 10-20 minute thesis film or equivalent interactive project
description_overview: In this final thesis track course, students will complete the post-production phase of their thesis projects, exhibit their finished works, and plan for their emergence into the field as media-makers. Post-production will include finishing steps such as sound mix, color correction and final digital file delivery. Exhibition will involve curating, planning and contextualizing the NUDocs show at Block Museum of their completed films or interactive media projects. Students will refine their artist statements, log-line and project descriptions in preparation of their MFA defenses and beyond. The course will also serve as an introduction to emerging into the field of documentary practice, including introduction to: curation, publicity, distribution, fundraising, festivals, and sustainability, culminating in reflection on individual career plans.

title: RTVF 374-0-20 Topics in Cinematography
description_overview: Examine basic principles of the combination art and craft that is cinematography and produce work exploring those principles.

title: RTVF 379-0-20 Topics in Film/Video/Audio Production
description_evaluation_method: Students will be graded on professionalism and the strength of the finished episode.
description_overview: This course is by permission only. Students were selected through a crew petition held by the student executive producers of the sitcom. All students are members of the crew. Students will collectively produce a sitcom that was written in a fall writing course.

title: RTVF 379-0-21 Topics in Film/Video/Audio Production
description_overview:
An introduction to various narrative forms (e.g. elliptical, minimalist, fractured, parallel, micro-fiction, episodic, environmental, ensemble, et al) that scramble notions of traditional "hero centered" three-act structure and posit alternate world views to narrative causality. The class will view and analyze a range of representative films with accompanied readings from a practitioners point of view (e.g. Wong Kar-Wai's In The Mood For Love, Julie Dash's Daughters of the Dust, Athina Tsangari's Chevalier, Chantal Akerman's The Meetings of Anna, Luis Bunuel's Un Chien Andalou, Lindsay Anderson's If?, Michael Haneke's Code Unknown, Jane Campion's Peel, Lynne Ramsay's Small Deaths, Apichatpong Weerasethakul's Tropical Malady, Akira Kurosawa's Roshomon, Souleymane Cissé's Brightnesss, Alain Rene's Hiroshima Mon Amour, Leo Carax's Holy Motors, et al). Students will then write and create final short film projects positing their own narrative strategies working either as individuals or in pairs.

Warning: Please research the list of sample films above. Most films screened are counter-cultural works which were created to provoke a strong emotional response. Many contain what might be for some viewers disturbing depictions of violence and sexual content. Most are chosen because they are recognized by the field as exceptional works for narrative experimentation. You are encouraged to respond and critique each filmmaker's approach to discover more about your personal voice as an artist.

title: RTVF 379-0-22 Topics in Film/Video/Audio Production
description_overview:
A recent New York Times op-ed was cheerfully titled "The Darkness Where the Future Should Be." Climate change, political dysfunction, surveillance capitalism, online dating? things don't look great. (Sorry!) On the other hand, artists/writers/filmmakers have been rising to the representational challenge with creative depictions, warnings, and philosophical ruminations on human possibility, across a variety of genres (sci-fi, comedy et al). How will you rise to the challenge?


? All students will be shooting their final projects in this class. COSTS will vary according to the ambition of the project (there are small production grants available to the class).
? No late adds and you must be at the first class to hold your spot.
? We'll be pitching/brainstorming at the first class, details TBA.

title: RTVF 379-0-23 Topics in Film/Video/Audio Production
description_overview:
Satire: The use of humor, irony, exaggeration, or ridicule to expose and criticize the stupidity or vices of people (or society or institutions), particularly in the context of contemporary politics and other topical issues. It intends to improve humanity by criticizing its follies and foibles.

So here's the question: what do you care enough about to want to satirize it? A class on satire is a reverse way of discovering what you value. Additional challenge: It's easy to shoot fish in barrels, ie to ridicule the ridiculous. What about taking it to another level, ie being both satirical and subtle?

? All students will be shooting their final projects in this class. COSTS will vary according to the ambition of the project (there are small production grants available to the class).
? No late adds and you must be at the first class to hold your spot.
? We'll be pitching/brainstorming at the first class, details TBA.

title: RTVF 358-0-20 Topics in Improv
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 376-0-20 Topics in Interactive Media
description_overview: This course is a workshop for understanding the cultural context of video games through practical use of introductory game creation tools. The course aims to distinguish between how video games extend traditions of artistic exchange and how they offer novel and unexplored modes of communication unique to the medium. The course is designed to engender an active and critical perspective on what games are and how they relate to other cultural texts through analysis, discussion, production, and play. Students will have the opportunity to conceptualize their own game projects and select from a menu of approaches in order to resolve them. Students will be evaluated through active participation, individual exercises, reading responses, presentations, and unit projects in group critique. The course is designed for students with no prior game making experience, although students with experience are welcome to enroll.

title: RTVF 376-0-21 Topics in Interactive Media
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 360-0-20 Topics in Media Writing
description_overview:
In this class, students will pitch and create a half-hour comedy pilot for television. The emphasis
will be on developing a story's humor from the ground (or premise) up, creating compelling
characters, and developing our comedic voices.
There will be weekly assignments which include writing assignments, readings, and watching
half-hour comedies. Each student will be expected to develop a pitch for their original series,
write a first and final draft of a comedy pilot (25-30 pages), and engage in collaborative
workshop discussions.

title: RTVF 360-0-21 Topics in Media Writing
description_overview:
In this class, students will create original stories for the stage and screen in which they may
choose to play a lead or major role. Inspired by the current trend in television ( Insecure, Atlanta,
Girls, Fleabag, Curb Your Enthusiasm ) wherein the writer-actor is also a series creator and star,
this course will explore strategies for writing great roles for actors and using a writer-actor brain
to develop characters and stories. Students will not be required to play a major role in their piece
and previous acting experience is not required.
There will be weekly assignments which include writing assignments, readings, and watching
television and film. Each student will write a first draft of a television pilot, one-act play, or short
film, and a final draft (25-30 pages). Students will engage in collaborative workshop discussions
of one another's scripts.

title: RTVF 360-0-22 Topics in Media Writing
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 360-0-23 Topics in Media Writing
description_overview: In this class, we will utilize a variety of research methods as springboards for creating original content for the stage and screen. Through written exercises and field assignments we will explore ways to use facts and research to create compelling narratives that stick to the facts as well as stories and adaptations inspired by true events. We will study examples of plays, films, and television, which use research as jumping off points.

title: RTVF 360-0-24 Topics in Media Writing
description_evaluation_method: In-class participation;Writing/Development Assignments ;Script Outline;Final Scripts
description_overview: The phrase "strong female character" is often used to describe women written for screen and stage, but often writers equate "strength" with male-centric attributes or one-dimensional perfection. This workshop-based class will examine gender bias in media's portrayal of women and the artists who are breaking these biases. We will explore the mechanics of writing dialogue, story structure and relationships for complex, female-driven narratives. The class will be structured through lectures, reading assignments, viewing of streamed films, discussion, in-class viewing of film clips and workshop of student writing assignments. By the end of the quarter, each student will complete a full first draft of an original female-centric screenplay or television pilot.

title: RTVF 360-0-25 Topics in Media Writing
description_evaluation_method: Class participation, weekly writing assignments, final writing project of minimum 30 pages
description_overview: Artists have the opportunity to grapple with the most complex problems facing our communities. Whether we define community in a local, national, or global context, climate change is radically shifting our world right now. How can the tools of dramatic storytelling be used to combat the issues of climate change? How can writers subvert binaries such as man versus nature or destruction versus salvation to create nuanced, riveting narratives on ecological themes? How can we interrogate concepts like solastalgia (mourning an ecosystem) and climate justice, and offer aesthetic antidotes to the "issue play" approach to climate change narratives? We will explore these questions using examples ranging from Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard to Pixar's WALL-E in conjunction with scientific, journalistic, and historical research as templates for our own dramatic imaginations. Through weekly labs and writing prompts, writers will generate material for a full-length work (play, screenplay, or pilot) focusing on a discrete aspect of climate change that speaks most directly to them.

title: RTVF 360-0-26 Topics in Media Writing
description_evaluation_method: In-class participation ;Writing/Development Assignments ;Series Bible ;Episode Scripts
description_overview:
The evolution of the current content landscape has opened up a swath of opportunities for short form content creators. Streamers, studios, OTT platforms, and traditional TV networks are not only purchasing short-form content, but they are developing it from within.

The digital series has reached a point in the marketplace where is no longer just a stepping-stone to larger episodic projects, but a commercially and critically viable medium of its own.

In "Writing the Digital Series" students will craft new work on original series concepts that are positioned to take advantage of these opportunities. The class will work individually and as a group to shape multiple episodes that would be consider ?ready for production' at the end of the quarter.

title: RTVF 360-0-27 Topics in Media Writing
description_evaluation_method: Students will be evaluated based on writing progress and engagement with in-class discussions, screenings and fellow student evaluations.
description_overview: Students will learn how to create a feature-length screenplay for a limited budget. By creating and workshopping a completed first draft of a script, students will learn about story structure, personal filmmaking, self-producing, creative casting and other aspects of putting together a micro-budget movie.

title: RTVF 360-0-28 Topics in Media Writing
description_evaluation_method: Screenplays will be graded on their ability to creatively and effectively convey narrative, as well as professionalism.
description_overview: This is an advanced-level writing course with a focus on creating original screenplays that students could potentially produce during their time in RTVF. We'll do multiple idea-generating exercises to help come up with topics for their films; workshop ideas and screenplays together as a class; and discuss ways to move these finished screenplays into produced films. This course will focus on the short screenplay, but all concepts and fundamentals we cover will springboard students into upper-level courses where they will pursue longer-form projects.

title: RTVF 377-0-20 Topics in Non-fiction Media
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 378-0-20 Topics in Post-Production
description_overview:
This class will introduce you to the art and skill of color timing, AKA color correction. The class will be a rewarding mixture of the artistic and technical, with a deeply hands-on workshop-type of approach.

Using Davinci Resolve, you will learn the fundamentals in primary, secondary, and effects color correction, as well as stabilizing and tracking. While the focus of the class will be on DaVinci Resolve, we will also explore the color grading capabilities in Adobe Premiere. You'll be evaluated through several in-class exercises and one main project. There will be a final exam that takes the form of a practical exam. We will attempt to visit a post-production facility each quarter and may host a masterclass with a Chicago-based professional colorist.

title: RTVF 378-0-21 Topics in Post-Production
description_evaluation_method: Students will be evaluated based on individual assignments, a marketing and distribution plan for their own project, as well as attendance and class participation.
description_overview: What happens after your film is finished? How do you find an audience for your work? Do you need a distributor or can you tackle self-distribution? This course will explore how filmmakers can navigate the many potential pathways and platforms that are available in today's competitive distribution and exhibition landscape. We will discuss marketing, DIY and traditional distribution, festivals, audience engagement, and a range of potential outlets (online, broadcast, and brick-and-mortar) in order to help students develop a marketing and distribution strategy for their own non-fiction projects.

title: RTVF 378-0-22 Topics in Post-Production
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 370-0-20 Topics in Pre-Production
description_evaluation_method: Attendance/discussion participation, one short essay, one scheduling exercise and one final pitch presentation which includes a full shooting schedule and budget.
description_overview: Students will learn the fundamentals of film producing, from pre-production through distribution, primarily through the lens of independent/low-budget filmmaking. Emphasis will be placed on both applied research and hands-on practice through serving as producer on a student short film in pre-production or production during the quarter. Course guest speakers always includes local and nationally recognized film producers and filmmakers for real-world advice about the art of producing. You will be required to deliver an end-of-quarter pitch presentation supplying a detailed schedule and budget for the short film to which you are attached as a co-producer.

title: RTVF 230-0-20 Understanding Media Contexts
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 502-0-20 Writing Practicum
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: RTVF 563-0-20 Writing the TV Episode
description_overview: In this class, we will study the fundamentals of writing a teleplay from concept, logline, and treatment to story arc and season outline. Through reading assignments, viewing coursework, and written exercises we will explore ways to write TV episodes suited to a variety of interests, tastes, and aesthetics. We will study examples from TV of the past and present as well as more emerging web-based forms.

title: SAI 401-0-20 Topics in Sound Production
description_evaluation_method:
Students will be evaluated on the basis of:;
    ;
  • their proposal of, and adherence to, a plan of work for the quarter
    • ;
  • approximately 5 presentations on ongoing work over the course of the quarter.
    • ;
  • active participation in class discussion and critiques.
    • ;
description_overview: The purpose of this seminar is to provide structure and support for students in the Sound Arts and Industries program toward the completion of their Study in Sound. This is accomplished through a participatory format of presentation, discussion, and critique supporting the formulation and incremental refinement of each student's capstone project. This process will culminate in the final presentation of Study in Sound, in whatever format best suits the work accomplished. The format, scheduling, and execution of the final Study in Sound presentations will be done as a class project.

title: SAI 401-0-21 Topics in Sound Production
description_overview: This course continues the study of film sound through an exploration of 5.1 recording and mixing techniques. We will look at various examples of surround sound mixing for film and discuss the technology's potential for immersion, presence and spectacle. The idea of surround sound will be broadened to include examples of multi-channel sound art, and studies of acoustics across built environments. Class projects will include 5.1 mixing for film sequences, ambience recording for surround, and site-specific sound installations. Students entering the class should have basic knowledge of Pro Tools and sound recording techniques.

title: SAI 401-0-22 Topics in Sound Production
topic: Creative Uses of Field, Found and Archival Recordi
description_evaluation_method: Class participation, 3 assignments, class presentation, final project, attendance.
description_overview: In this project-based course, students are introduced to innovative conceptual and artistic production approaches for field recordings, "found" audio, and archival sound sources in contemporary art, radio, podcasting, journalism, and documentary practices. Students learn through listening examples and in-class discussion.

title: SAI 401-0-23 Topics in Sound Production
description_overview: Sound Synthesis is a comprehensive introduction to the underlying principles and creative techniques applied to analog and digital synthesizers. The course will integrate sound physics, aesthetics, history, perception, theory, and practice using in-class demonstrations, tutorials, readings, and listening sessions. We will cover various methods of sound synthesis such as subtractive, amplitude modulation, frequency modulation, and more, as well as investigate unique approaches to sample based sound design. Our primary tools will be Max/MSP and an analog modular synthesizer that students will have access to out of class time for projects and assignments. Evaluation will be based on a combination of class participation, assignments, and a final project. No prerequisites necessary, however some prior experience with Max/MSP is encouraged.

title: SAI 400-0-20 Topics in Sound Studies
description_evaluation_method:
Students will be assessed through: ;
    ;
  1. a portfolio of short response papers;
  2. three short videographic essays made using Adobe Premiere and clips from Lynch's oeuvre;
  3. in-class reading quizzes;
  4. a short critical review of the new "Twin Peaks" VR experience,
    5. ;
description_overview:
We know very well that media texts are collaborative projects: when we see the credits roll at the end of a major film for example, we see hundreds of names and numerous specialized tasks. And yet the idea of an individual creator still has a powerful hold over the way most of us think about and experience the media. What does it mean to be an "author" in the creative industries? What is the nature of creative work? How are artistic reputations constructed and understood? What role do critics and audiences play in that process? Why so some media texts have authors and others don't? How does collaboration work in the creative industries? In this course we will investigate these and other questions through the analysis of the transmedia career of David Lynch.

Lynch's output covers a remarkably wide range of production contexts and media forms, encompassing visual art, film, television, photography, furniture design, popular music, online films, digital cinematography, and virtual reality. Lynch can be seen as the ultimate crossover artist: a cult filmmaker who went on to have a hit network television series ("Twin Peaks") the same year as winning the Golden Palm at the Cannes Film Festival. Starting his career as a painter, he emerged as an avant-garde filmmaker in the early 1970s. After his first feature Eraserhead achieved the status of a cult classic on the "midnight movie" circuit, Lynch jumped into mainstream filmmaking, and has become one of the rare directors to find success with general audiences, cult fans, and academics. Films such as Blue Velvet became touchstones for film theorists during the 1980s, and are still discussed in academic circles today. Lynch has never been without his critics, and his work has come under fire for its depiction of women, sexual violence, race, and class. Lynch has often had creative control over his projects, and yet his distinctive "Lynchian" signature was forged through long-standing collaborative relationships with a cohort of actors, composers, editors, and sound designers. Lynch is thus a remarkably fertile case study for a consideration of media authorship, modes of collaboration in the creative industries, the history of film culture since the 1970s, the various logics of film, television, and digital media, the importance of sound design in audio-visual media, the representation of race, class, and gender, and a range of other issues.

title: THEATRE 470-3-20 Acting 3: Shakespeare 1
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: THEATRE 273-3-20 Acting I
description_overview: The acting course at NU is a developmental course of three years that teaches the study of theatre, and particularly dramatic literature, from the actor's point of view. Much of what we do seeks to establish strong group dynamics so the acting cohort and teacher stay together for the three years. The first year's study concentrates on the actor's creative capacities, and the communicating instrument is the self. The primary creative responsibility of the actor is to generate human character within the given circumstances of a play. While each teacher organizes the work individually, all agree on fundamentals, which include: Sensory Perception and Response, Observation, Imagination, Dramatic Character Creation, and Text Analysis.Get permission number, have fulfilled freshman prereq., be a theater major

title: THEATRE 373-3-20 Acting II: Analysis and Performance
description_overview: This quarter will be devoted to the study of the plays and the playing style of Modern Realism. Class will consist of scene study, with text taken from Anton Chekov and Henrik Ibsen.

title: THEATRE 373-3-21 Acting II: Analysis and Performance
description_overview: In the second year we study the traditional canon of Western Drama to discover what each contributes to the theory, principles, and techniques of interpretation of drama from the point of view of the actor. In this first quarter we will focus on Greek Tragedy, perhaps the starkest form of drama. We will experiment with epic-sized characters expressing the deepest of human emotions, while trying to unite the voice work from sophomore year with an understanding of the text. We will experiment with different ideas in staging using some of the trappings of the period (masks, robes, headdress, shoes), with the ritual aspects of the dramas, with movement and sound. Also, and of utmost importance: the original thespians were men. I encourage all of you to explore all roles, without regard to sexual/gender identity. Women will play the male roles! Men will explore the female roles. This is quarter in which I challenge the students and their notions of identity.

title: THEATRE 373-3-22 Acting II: Analysis and Performance
description_overview: This quarter will be devoted to the study of the plays and the playing style of Modern Realism. Class will consist of scene study, with text taken from Anton Chekov and Henrik Ibsen.

title: THEATRE 373-3-23 Acting II: Analysis and Performance
description_overview: This quarter will be devoted to the study of the plays and the playing style of Modern Realism. Class will consist of scene study, with text taken from Anton Chekov and Henrik Ibsen.

title: THEATRE 373-3-24 Acting II: Analysis and Performance
description_overview: This quarter will be devoted to the study of the plays and the playing style of Modern Realism. Class will consist of scene study, with text taken from Anton Chekov and Henrik Ibsen.

title: THEATRE 375-0-20 Advanced Acting Topics
description_overview:
This course is designed to build on the student's knowledge and experience of Shakespeare from junior year of the Acting Sequence. It exposes the student actor to a variety of Shakespeare's plays through in-depth analysis, rehearsal and performance of monologue and scene work, specifically designed to challenge and expand each student's acting skills through heightened language. Students learn to use the First Folio Technique as a tool to discovering Shakespeare's inherent clues about performance. Special attention is given to the rehearsal and performance of large ensemble scenes and the selection of audition-caliber Shakespeare monologues.

The class is designed to enable the student actor to fully inhabit Shakespeare's text and characters in a personal and believable way, embodying his language with clarity, imagination and passion.

title: THEATRE 375-0-21 Advanced Acting Topics
description_overview: This course will examine how one navigates the entertainment industry as an artist. We will learn about agents and casting, auditioning, headshots/resumes, cover letters, on-camera work, and other important matters. We will consider some of the minutia that seems daunting at the start of a career, i.e. taxes, unions, and even how different cities function as locations for actors. We will discuss types and we will roleplay in contract negotiation. This is a lecture/discussion course, but it requires full, physical participation, and grades will depend upon such.

title: THEATRE 375-0-22 Advanced Acting Topics
description_overview: Scene study focusing on modern and contemporary American playwrights whose work explores the intricacies of family relationships and family conflict, as well as new definitions of what constitutes family. Specific plays and scenes will be chosen to reflect the diversity and experiences of the co-hort. Possible playwrights may include: Sarah Ruhl, Tarell Alvin McCraney, Eugene O'Neill, Tennessee Williams, Caryl Churchill; Luis Alfaro; Rebecca Gilman, Lydia Diamond, Sam Shepard, Ayad Akhtar, etc.

title: THEATRE 375-0-23 Advanced Acting Topics
description_overview: Exploring the plays that interest the individual students enrolled: what haven't you had the chance to work on over these three years, or what would you like to re-visit?"

title: THEATRE 355-0-20 Advanced Creating the Musical
description_overview: Bringing new genres of music to the stage, celebrating musicals with the dramatic integrity of plays, and foregrounding questions of identity and social impact...What counts as a musical is rapidly transforming in recent years. In this workshop class, we will draw inspiration from recent trends and work in collaborative teams to write and compose musical scenes and songs for the stage. We will analyze musical scenes and numbers from 21st century shows that are expanding new boundaries for what and how musical theatre can be, and add our own stories and songs to the mix. All levels of experience welcome. (This course can be counted toward the "Creating the Musical" module.)

title: THEATRE 333-2-20 Advanced Creative Drama
description_overview: Explores improvised drama as a teaching method and a means of learning for the elementary school child. Theory and practice through reading, discussion, films, observation. Course culminates with extended teaching projects with children from the local schools.

title: THEATRE 383-3-20 Advanced Playwriting Sequence
description_overview: This class will function as a playwrights' workshop. Through writing exercises and weekly workshops, students will learn techniques for rewriting and developing early drafts of play scripts.

title: THEATRE 464-1-20 Advanced Studies in Costume Design
description_overview: Individual design process, involving text interpretation, character analysis, and research, in response to texts of various theatrical genres.

title: THEATRE 462-1-20 Advanced Studies in Lighting Design
description_overview: In this class you will engage with two previously realized productions by creating lighting designs of professional, production ready quality. You will be provided with production relevant material including source material, scenic (and costume, if available) designs, and technical plans. Through the class you will investigate and utilize a proven design process to complete you work. Weekly critiques of work in process will allow you to make work, present, and revise, focused towards the final design presentation. Your work will be challenged and you will be held accountable for your ideas and methods. Major emphasis in critique will be given to the compositional and dramaturgical appropriateness of your design ideas. We will also address industry standard graphic standards.

title: THEATRE 463-1-20 Advanced Studies in Scenic Design
description_overview: Script and the action of the play as the foundation for scene design. Use of initial reading of the script, combined with research in forming design ideas.

title: THEATRE 351-6-23 Advanced Voice VI

title: THEATRE 171-0-20 Basic Acting
description_evaluation_method: Presentation of Scene Work
description_overview:
Using exercises, outside assignments, observation of life, and improvisation you will be introduced to basic principles of acting. You will learn the fundamentals of creating character and a simple method to turn the written word into action. Finally, you will apply these principles toward scene work using simple "content-less" scenes and a scene from a play.

Although there are written components to the course, the essence of the class is in the DOING. You must come ready to risk, to play, to work, and to question. You must also spend significant time outside of the class working with scene partners.

title: THEATRE 171-0-21 Basic Acting
description_evaluation_method: Presentation of Scene Work
description_overview:
Using exercises, outside assignments, observation of life, and improvisation you will be introduced to basic principles of acting. You will learn the fundamentals of creating character and a simple method to turn the written word into action. Finally, you will apply these principles toward scene work using simple "content-less" scenes and a scene from a play.

Although there are written components to the course, the essence of the class is in the DOING. You must come ready to risk, to play, to work, and to question. You must also spend significant time outside of the class working with scene partners.

title: THEATRE 420-1-20 Collaboration: American Realism
description_overview: First in a series exploring collaboration between stage director and designers for production. Focus: collaborative process; realistic and naturalistic American drama.

title: THEATRE 420-3-20 Collaboration: Shakespeare in the 21st Century
description_overview: Third in a series exploring collaboration between stage director and designers for production. Focus: Shakespeare.

title: THEATRE 255-0-20 Creating the Musical
description_overview:
This class will explore the fundamentals of musical storytelling with the focus on the
creation of music theatre text (book and lyrics). Through an examination of the musicals
that are the historical backbone of our music theatre heritage and an exploration of the
process of creating book and lyrics, the class will offer an understanding of the basics of
story structure, plot development, character, conflict and form specific to the writing of a
musical theatre piece. In the class we will outline a full length original or adapted
musical, define the scene/song structure of the book and complete the book and lyrics for
the first 10-12 minutes of the show.

title: THEATRE 221-2-20 Design Process: Costume
description_overview: This course is an introduction to the process of costume design. Through the coursework and in-class presentations you will learn the steps to the design process for a costume designer for theatre. You will become familiar with how to approach a script from the perspective of a costume designer, and generate ideas based on visual and written research that will be presented in a visual format (i.e. drawing, collage, etc.).

title: THEATRE 221-3-20 Design Process: Lighting
description_evaluation_method: Critique based class - Evaluation through discussion and presentation.
description_overview: This course will develop students' ability to see and discuss light with an established point of view within a context of design for the stage. The course will explore elements and principles of light through visual and verbal presentations. Students will learn to develop conceptual lighting design ideas based on text analysis, research, and various creative steps a lighting designer completes in order to develop a design.

title: THEATRE 221-1-20 Design Process: Scene
description_evaluation_method: Midterm and final examinations. Project work throughout. Attendance.
description_overview: Intro to scenic design is a 10 week course applying the major principles of design to the physical stage. Students will learn the necessary skills, including but not limited to, analysis, storyboarding, model making, and hand drafting in order to develop a final scenic design for a play or musical.

title: THEATRE 374-0-1 Dialects for the Stage
description_overview: Using the International Phonetic Alphabet, dialect recordings and selected text, students are given the tools to acquire a variety of dialects for performance in theatre and film. Principal dialects covered are standard British (Received Pronunciation), Cockney, North of England, Irish (North and South), French, Russian, German. Prerequisites: Theatre 170 Voice for Performance and Theatre 272 Voice for Shakespeare and permission of instructor.

title: THEATRE 472-0-1 Dramatic and Aesthetic Theory for Stage Designers
description_overview: Students will analyze big ideas of dramatic theory and aesthetic theory - concepts that have defined what is important about theatre and how it might be advanced as a form, as well as philosophical points of view concerning the beautiful, the ugly, and how we think about it - by investigating the work of thinkers within the theatre, and from the broader art-making world, from the mid 19th century to present day, considering their work in their historical context and in our present circumstances. By drawing synthetic conclusions from chronologically and philosophically incongruent sources, students will gain a more sophisticated understanding of current practice and will mature their own points of view as theatre artists. Students will read curated excerpts, lead and participate in discussion, and set forth analysis and opinion in Accountability Statements and Synthesis Papers, culminating in a Final Creative Project.

title: THEATRE 325-4-20 Drawing & Painting for the Theatre: Drafting
THEATRE 211-0-20 Fundamentals of Stage Directing
description_overview: This course is designed to introduce students to the principals and techniques of stage direction. Students will develop and hone their individual creative impulses, learn essential text analysis and dramaturgical skills, and get practical experience in a rehearsal laboratory. Particular emphasis will be placed on the development of specific language skills to have command and clarity of ideas when speaking to actors and designers about their work. Students will have the opportunity to expand their awareness of contemporary plays, playwrights, and professional directors while examining practices in the field today. Most importantly, student directors will articulate their unique individual points of view on a selection of contemporary plays as they discover what a play means to them and how that translates to the art they make.

title: THEATRE 402-0-20 Graduate Colloquium
description_overview: This class is a collaboration between the MFA directing students and the MFA playwrights as well as advanced undergraduate directors. Students in this advanced writing class will workshop a complete draft of a play that is approximately 60 pages in length (the page limit will be expanded if the play is chosen for additional workshopping in the spring quarter). The full draft will be read out loud in class and MFA and advanced undergraduate directing students will workshop and present scenes from the play. Students will serve as actors during the reading and workshopping of the play. Playwriting students will be expected to workshop a recent work. An older project may be workshopped if it has undergone significant revisions. This is the first part of a two part class. The second part is a production class which will run in the spring (likely Thursdays 11am-150pm). Four plays from part one of the class will be selected to receive workshop productions in part two. This will culminate in a weekend festival in June where the produced plays will be showcased. ?In addition to second and third year graduate directors, this class is open to undergraduate Junior and Senior advanced directing students by permission only. Your participation in New Play Collab I will automatically guarantee you a spot in New Play Collab II in the Spring, where you will direct a workshop of one of the selected plays for the New Work Festival. Please only apply if you can commit to taking the course both Winter and Spring quarters. Interested undergrads please submit a paragraph that expresses your interest, as well as listing your year, primary directing professor, and significant directing experience to Professors Shana Cooper at shanacooper@northwestern.edu and Thomas Bradshaw at t-bradshaw@northwestern.edu, as well as copy TA Danielle Roos at DanielleRoose2020@northwestern.edu.

title: THEATRE 252-0-20 Intermediate MT Techniques
description_overview: This course deals with the unique challenges of acting through song. Students develop a reliable process for preparing a role that is adaptable to a wide range of projects and styles of direction in musical theatre. Students hone their artistic voice through the synthesis of text and music analysis, acting, singing, and movement.

title: THEATRE 252-0-21 Intermediate MT Techniques
description_overview: This course deals with the unique challenges of acting through song. Students develop a reliable process for preparing a role that is adaptable to a wide range of projects and styles of direction in musical theatre. Students hone their artistic voice through the synthesis of text and music analysis, acting, singing, and movement.

title: THEATRE 394-0-24 Internship in Theatre Practice

title: THEATRE 376-0-20 Intro to Acting for the Screen
description_overview: This course will introduce RTVF and Theater students to the craft of acting for the screen. With an emphasis on the actor/director relationship, it will address practices for creating and portraying characters as well as the more technical concerns of how actors place themselves in relationship to the camera for the most effective appearance onscreen. Students in this course will perform in (and, in some cases, direct) a number of exercises to build acting skills in front of the camera, in projects - both in-class and out-of-class - designed to focus on cinematic storytelling achieved primarily through performance rather than primarily through directorial technique, cinematography, editing, and sound design.

title: THEATRE 281-0-1 Intro to Playwriting
description_overview: A general overview of the playwriting craft. Students read plays from the canon as well as contemporary plays, complete exercises that flex different writing muscles, and ultimately craft the beginning of an original full-length play. Open to students of all experience level. This course is a pre-requisite for both the Playwriting Module and the Advanced Playwriting Sequence. Instructor permission required.

title: THEATRE 347-0-20 Latinx Theatre
description_overview: This course examines the emergence and development of Latinx theatre in the United States from the vaudeville circuit, to street theatre/protests, and finally to Broadway. Representative works by Latinx authors and artists will be discussed alongside issues of labor and immigration, income inequality and economic mobility, gender and sexuality, generational gaps and hybridized identities, stereotypes and representation in popular culture, and the United State's relationship with Latin American nations.

title: THEATRE 244-1-20 Modern & Contemp Theatre: Modern
description_overview:
What do we as theatre artists do with plays that are unstageable? How do we as theatre scholars make sense of scripts that are nonsensical? This course investigates the limits, boundaries, and possibilities of theatre by exploring modern theatrical texts which
contain considerable challenges for live performance. These plays include nonsensical stage directions, technically difficult feats, and censor-worthy content and explore complex themes like death, the supernatural, dreams, and nightmares through experimentation
with form, style, and genre.

This seminar focuses on a wide array of theatre movements during the late-nineteenth and early-twentieth centuries in Europe and North America that aimed to break away from traditional theatrical conventions and create new modes of representation onstage. Throughout
the quarter, we will read dramas and manifestos that defined modern movements such as Realism, Naturalism, Symbolism, Expressionism, Futurism, Surrealism, Theatre of Cruelty, and Absurdism. We will discuss questions such as: is it possible to represent absence
onstage? Can playwrights personify death without embodying it? Is narrative necessary for theatre? Can dramatists "script" chance or randomness? Students will be expected to contribute to classroom discussion, participate in creative group projects, and construct
a final research paper. (Content Warning: Some of the texts we will be reading are explicitly violent and sexually graphic.)

title: THEATRE 471-3-20 Movement 3: Integration/Practice
description_overview: Contact the department for further information

title: THEATRE 256-0-20 Musicianship for Actors
description_overview: Musicianship for Actors is designed to develop a high level of musical literacy for every student actor, regardless of his/her incoming musical ability. The class aims to bridge the gap between the classroom and the real world application of music reading through the practical application of the pitch elements of music (harmony and melody) and temporal elements of music (rhythm, meter, etc.). Daily class activities include sight-singing, ear training, keyboard application, improvisation, and critical listening. Musical material will be drawn from the music theatre repertoire.

title: THEATRE 256-0-21 Musicianship for Actors
description_overview: Musicianship for Actors is designed to develop a high level of musical literacy for every student actor, regardless of his/her incoming musical ability. The class aims to bridge the gap between the classroom and the real world application of music reading through the practical application of the pitch elements of music (harmony and melody) and temporal elements of music (rhythm, meter, etc.). Daily class activities include sight-singing, ear training, keyboard application, improvisation, and critical listening. Musical material will be drawn from the music theatre repertoire.

title: THEATRE 382-0-20 Playwriting Genres
description_overview:
American poet Gary Snyder famously wrote, "Nature is not a place you visit. It is home." One of the most pressing subjects of our time is the destruction of nature and the climate crisis. What are the stories we might tell on stage that help capture this immanent threat, and how might we think about revering nature as a rallying cry to take better care of it? Students will wrestle these questions as they craft a one-act play.
Open to students of all levels of writing experience. Instructor permission required.

title: THEATRE 121-0-20 Production Laboratory
description_evaluation_method: Students are graded on attitude, skill, growth and initiative in addition to attendance demonstrated on their production assignment.
description_overview: This course is a non-credit registration for students fulfilling production lab requirements. Students are assigned to a production lab in one of the Wirtz Center's Production Shops.

title: THEATRE 121-0-21 Production Laboratory
description_evaluation_method: Students are graded on attitude, skill, growth and initiative in addition to attendance demonstrated on their production assignment.

title: THEATRE 121-0-25 Production Laboratory
description_evaluation_method: Students are graded on attitude, skill, growth and initiative in addition to attendance demonstrated on their production assignment.
